questionList.questionText:
A study is conducted to evaluate the amino acid phenylalanine in preterm newborns who were fed different human milk diets.  Twenty-four very low-birth-weight, preterm newborns were randomly assigned to one of the following feeding groups:

  • Group I: banked human milk plus 5% commercial fortifier with bovine protein

  • Group II: banked human milk plus evaporated fortifier derived from modified human milk

  • Group III: banked human milk plus lyophilized fortifier derived from modified human milk

The newborns received one of the group diets until full diet was attained at 15 days.  Plasma amino acid analysis was performed on the first and last day of feeding.  Analysis of data includes an analysis of variance (ANOVA) to compare group mean levels of phenylalanine in plasma at Day 0 and at Day 15, along with 95% confidence intervals to estimate ANOVA-adjusted means for each group at each time point.  An excerpt of results is shown below:

Based on these findings, which of the following statements is most accurate?
questionList.explanationText:
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the means of ≥3 independent groups.  The null (H0) and alternative (Ha) hypotheses of interest in an ANOVA are:

  • H0: μ1 = μ2 = μ3 ... = μk (ie, all means are equal)

  • Ha: All means are not equal

Therefore, an ANOVA that is not statistically significant (eg, p ≥ 0.05) indicates that all group means are equal whereas an ANOVA that is statistically significant (eg, p < 0.05) indicates only that at least 1 group mean is different from the rest.  However, an ANOVA does not determine which group means differ—further evaluation is required to determine the specific difference.

In this question, ANOVA is used to determine whether the mean levels of phenylalanine in preterm newborn plasma differ among 3 feeding groups.  The ANOVA test at Day 0 shows no evidence of a significant difference among group means (p = 0.93) (Choice A), but the ANOVA test at Day 15 shows evidence of a significant difference among group means (p = 0.01) (Choice D).  This does not mean that each group has a mean plasma phenylalanine level that is statistically significantly different from the other 2 group means (Choice B); instead, it means that the group means are not all the same at Day 15.

(Choice C)  The study does not directly compare the mean plasma phenylalanine level at Day 0 to the mean plasma phenylalanine level at Day 15 (ie, pre-post comparison).  Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether there is a significant increase in mean plasma phenylalanine levels in all 3 groups from Day 0 to Day 15.

Educational objective:
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) compares the means of independent groups and determines only whether at least 1 group mean differs from the others.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Statistical tests

answerChoiceList.choice: At Day 0, there is a statistically significant difference in mean plasma phenylalanine levels among groups
At Day 15, each group has a mean plasma phenylalanine level that is statistically significantly different from that of the other 2 group means
There is evidence of a significant increase in mean plasma phenylalanine levels in all 3 groups from Day 0 to Day 15
There is no statistically significant difference in mean plasma phenylalanine level among groups at either Day 0 or Day 15
The mean plasma phenylalanine levels of Groups I, II, and III are not all the same at Day 15

questionList.questionText: Two studies were conducted on different samples from the same population to assess the relationship between oral contraceptive use and the risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT).  Study A showed an increased risk of DVT among oral contraceptive users, with a relative risk of 2.0 and a 95% confidence interval of 1.2-2.8.  Study B showed a relative risk of 2.01 and a 95% confidence interval of 0.8-3.1.  Which of the following statements is most likely to be true regarding these 2 studies?
questionList.explanationText:
Statistical significance:
Relationship between confidence intervals and p-values

"A ___ confidence interval that does not include the null value…"

95%

99%

"…corresponds to p < ___."

0.05

0.01

The relative risk (RR) is the risk of an outcome (eg, deep venous thrombosis [DVT]) in the exposed group (eg, oral contraceptive [OC] users) divided by the risk of that outcome in the unexposed group.  If the RR = 1.0 (null value), then there is no association between exposure and outcome (or disease).  An RR >1.0 indicates that exposure is associated with increased risk of disease.  An RR <1.0 means that exposure is associated with decreased risk of disease.  The RR in studies A and B was >1.0, suggesting increased DVT risk among OC users.

For a result to be considered statistically significant, its corresponding confidence interval (CI) must NOT contain the null value.  When the 95% CI does not include the null value, this gives a corresponding p-value <0.05 and the association between exposure and outcome is considered statistically significant.  A p-value <0.05 reflects that there is a very low probability that the result was due to chance alone; formally, the p-value is the probability of observing a given (or more extreme) result due to chance alone, assuming that the null hypothesis is true.  The RR obtained in study A (RR = 2.0) is statistically significant as its 95% confidence interval (1.2-2.8) does not include the null value (because it does not include 1.0) (Choice C).  The 95% confidence interval for study B (0.8-3.1) includes the null value of 1.0, and thus the study is not statistically significant; in other words, the corresponding p-value would be >0.05 (Choice A).

The CI in study B is wider than in study A, and it contains the null value (ie, not statistically significant).  This wider CI is most likely due to a smaller sample size, which decreases the study's power (ie, its ability to detect the difference between exposed and unexposed subjects).  Increasing sample size would increase the study's power and make the CI narrower.  By doing so, the null value would likely have been excluded (as in study A), thus increasing statistical significance.  Although there are several causes of a wide CI, small sample size is a common one.

(Choices B and D)  Measurements that lack accuracy (proximity to the true value) generally reflect a bias (systematic deviation from the true value).  The accuracy of the studies cannot be judged because there is no information on how they were designed and conducted.

Educational objective:
The power of a study represents its ability to detect a difference between 2 groups (eg, exposed versus unexposed) when there truly is a difference.  Increasing the sample size increases the power of a study and consequently narrows the confidence interval surrounding the point estimate.  Confidence intervals express statistical significance and are interrelated with p-values.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

answerChoiceList.choice: The p-value in study B is likely <0.05
The result in study A is not accurate
The result in study A is not statistically significant
The result in study B is likely biased
The sample size is likely smaller in study B than study A

questionList.questionText: The neurorehabilitation unit at a local hospital conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effects of high-intensity treadmill training (HITT) against low-intensity treadmill training (LITT) on gait ability, quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and cost of walking in patients with chronic stroke.  Thirty patients were randomized to either HITT or LITT, but 9 patients in the HITT group and 3 patients in the LITT group dropped out of the study.  The statistical analysis was conducted following a per-protocol principle.  Based on this information, which of the following is of most concern regarding the analysis?
questionList.explanationText:
Study dropouts may bias estimates of treatment effect.  For example, in a placebo-controlled, randomized trial of interventions (ie, high-intensity treadmill training [HITT] group vs low-intensity treadmill training [LITT] group), adverse effects on health may cause a greater proportion of patients with more severe illness to drop out from the HITT group than from the LITT group.  This means that at the trial's conclusion, the HITT group may have a smaller proportion of more severely ill patients than the LITT group (eg, selection bias).  This could distort the estimation of the effect of the interventions (eg, confounding bias).

Per-protocol (PP) analysis compares treatment groups in a randomized trial by including in the analysis only those participants who strictly adhered to and completed the protocol (ie, it excludes dropouts).  Therefore, it provides an estimate of the effect of an intervention assuming an (unrealistic) perfect scenario in which all participants were retained and completed treatments as planned (Choice C).  However, clinical settings (eg, medical practices) almost inevitably include dropouts, so PP analysis misrepresents (typically overestimates) the effect of the intervention.

In contrast, an intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis includes all participants as initially allocated after randomization, regardless of what happens during the study period (eg, keeping the HITT and LITT dropouts in their respective groups for analysis).  ITT analysis estimates the effect of assigning (rather than receiving) an intervention; compared to PP analysis, ITT analysis could lead to a more conservative estimate of the effect of the intervention (Choices D and E).  However, it closely mirrors the expected number of dropouts in a real-life situation, so ITT analysis reflects the (realistic) expected effect of the intervention in a medical practice setting.

(Choice A)  Participants drop out of a study before any statistical analysis is conducted, so the type of statistical analysis does not affect the dropout rates in a study.

Educational objective:
Per-protocol analysis includes only those participants who strictly adhered to and completed the study protocol (ie, nondropouts).  This approach tends to provide an estimate of the true effect of an intervention for a perfect scenario, but it can overestimate the effect of the intervention in a practical clinical setting.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Per-treatment analysis

answerChoiceList.choice: It will increase the chance of differential dropouts between intervention groups
It will misrepresent the effect of the intervention among patients of a medical practice
It will not estimate the effect of the intervention in patients who completed the study
It will only estimate the effect of assigning the intervention to patients
It will result in a more conservative estimate of the effect of the intervention

questionList.questionText: In recent years, more people have been diagnosed with leukemia in town A than in town B.  Which of the following study designs would be best suited to determine whether the town location is related to the apparent difference in leukemia incidence in these 2 towns?
questionList.explanationText:
Incidence is defined as the number of new cases of a disease arising in an at-risk population over a specified time period.  Subjects without the disease are followed over a period of time to discover how many eventually develop that disease.  A cohort study is an observational study in which groups are chosen based upon presence or absence of one or more risk factors.  All subjects are observed over time for development of the disease of interest, allowing for estimation of incidence within the total population and comparison of incidences between groups.

In this example, the town of residence is the risk factor of interest and leukemia is the disease of interest.  Residents of town A and town B could be followed for a period of time and the incidence of leukemia determined for each site.  Comparing the incidences between the 2 towns would allow determination of the relative risk for developing leukemia in town A compared to town B.  This would be an example of a prospective cohort study; retrospective cohort studies review prior records to determine incidence of a disease of interest in groups of subjects chosen based on presence or absence of a risk factor.

(Choice A)  In a case-control study, subjects with the disease of interest (cases) are compared to an otherwise similar group of disease-free subjects (controls).  Information is then collected about exposure to risk factors.  A case-control study is retrospective and meant to determine associations between risk factors and disease occurrence.  An odds ratio can be calculated in a case-control study, but the incidence of a disease cannot.

(Choice B)  A case series is a study involving only patients already diagnosed with a condition of interest.  A case series can be helpful in determining the natural history of uncommon conditions, but it provides no information about disease incidence.

(Choice C)  A clinical trial compares the therapeutic benefit of different interventions in patients already diagnosed with a particular disease.  Clinical trials cannot be used to determine disease incidence.

(Choice E)  In ecological studies, the unit of observation is a population.  Disease rates and exposures are measured in 2 (or more) populations, and the association between disease rates and exposures is determined.  However, results about associations at the population level may not translate to the individual level.  Ecological studies cannot be used to determine incidence.

Educational objective:
A cohort study design is best for determining the incidence of a disease.  Comparing the incidence of the disease in 2 populations, with and without a given risk factor, allows for calculation of relative risk.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk, rate, prevalence and incidence

questionList.questionText:
A 68-year-old man with severe knee osteoarthritis comes to the office to discuss options for total knee arthroplasty (TKA).  The patient wants to know which type of prosthesis will help him return to his active lifestyle.  A recent study compared the 10-year clinical, radiologic, and survival outcomes of single-radius (SR) prostheses and multiradius (MR) posterior-stabilized prostheses in TKA.  In terms of clinical outcomes, the study reported that health survey scores were all significantly improved in both groups at the final follow-up visit (p < 0.05), with no significant differences between the 2 groups (p > 0.05).  The SR group had significantly less anterior knee pain and painless crepitation (p < 0.05) compared to the MR group.  Radiologic results in terms of radiolucent lines and component position angle showed no differences between the groups (p > 0.05).  The Kaplan-Meier survival curve estimates at 10 years are shown below.

Based on the findings of this study, which of the following conclusions is justified?
questionList.explanationText:
The Kaplan-Meier (KM) statistical method is used in survival analysis to analyze time-to-event data, which refers to the time from entry into a study until an event of interest (eg, onset of disease, death) occurs.  This method takes into account that any potential event (eg, event of interest, lost to follow-up, dropped out) may occur at different points in time for different study participants.  For this reason, the KM method compares the rate at which these events occur during the entire study period rather than at the end of the study only.

The KM curve depicts the probability of survival at various time points during the study, calculated based on the proportion of subjects who are alive (or at risk for an event of interest) at different times.

  • The x-axis denotes time from beginning to end of the study period.

  • The y-axis denotes cumulative event-free survival starting from 1.0 or 100% (ie, 100% of patients have not experienced any event) at the beginning of the study.  As the study progresses, events occur and the proportion of subjects at risk for an event of interest decreases, causing a downward dip in the curve.

The KM method is also used to compare survival curves between 2 groups (eg, comparing 2 different treatments, comparing a treatment group to a control [placebo] group).  The statistical test that compares KM survival curves is the log-rank test.  A p-value less than significance level alpha (usually 0.05) indicates a significant difference in survival curves between 2 groups, unlike what is seen in this study (p = 0.57 > 0.05).

This study reported improved health survey scores in both the single-radius (SR) prosthesis group and the multiradius (MR) prosthesis group, but there were no differences between the groups (p > 0.05).  It also showed no difference in radiologic results (p > 0.05) or survival results at long-term follow-up (ie, log-rank test: p > 0.05) between the groups (Choices A and B).

However, SR prostheses were associated with less anterior knee pain than MR prostheses (p < 0.05).  This means that, although both prostheses led to satisfactory outcomes, SR prostheses resulted in less anterior knee pain compared with MR prostheses.  Therefore, the SR prosthesis should be recommended because it may result in better pain management (Choices D and E).

Educational objective:
The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a commonly used graphic representation of the probabilities that subjects survive in a study without an event of interest.  The event-free survival rates of ≥2 study groups can be compared; they are statistically different only if the p-value is less than 0.05.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Life expectancy and survival statistics

answerChoiceList.choice: An MR prosthesis should be recommended because its use resulted in better overall survival estimates
An SR prosthesis should be recommended because it has greater 10-year postoperative survival estimates
Both prostheses had satisfactory outcomes, but the SR prosthesis should be recommended because it may be better for pain management
Either prosthesis can be recommended because there was no significant difference in outcomes between the 2 groups
Neither prosthesis should be recommended because there was no significant difference in outcomes between groups

questionList.questionText:
A prospective cohort study is conducted to assess the relationship between elevated C-reactive protein level (exposure) and the development of acute coronary syndrome (disease).  A sample of 100 adults age >45 is categorized according to their C-reactive protein (CRP) levels.  After a 5-year follow-up period, the following data were obtained:

CRP level elevatedCRP level normalTotal
Diseased102030
Non-diseased106070
Total2080100

What is the 5-year risk of getting acute coronary syndrome in subjects with elevated CRP levels?
questionList.explanationText:
Risk is the statistical likelihood of experiencing an adverse event.  In epidemiology, risk is a measure of incidence of a disease of interest; that is, the probability of developing the disease over a certain period of time (eg, 5 years).  To calculate the risk of a disease of interest (eg, acute coronary syndrome [ACS]) in subjects with an exposure of interest (eg, elevated C-reactive protein [CRP] level), divide:

number of subjects with the exposure who develop the disease
(eg, number of subjects with elevated CRP level who develop ACS = 10)

by

total number of subjects with the exposure (ie, exposed/at risk) 
(eg, total number of subjects with elevated CRP level = 20)

In this example, 10/20 = 0.5, which is interpreted as a 50% probability of developing ACS in 5 years.

Note that the data are not presented in the standard 2 x 2 format (with exposure status in the rows, and disease status in the columns), requiring appropriate interpretation of the values in each cell.

(Choice B)  The 5-year risk of developing ACS in all study subjects is 30/100 = 0.3 (30%).

(Choice C)  The 5-year risk of developing ACS in subjects without elevated CRP levels is 20/80 = 0.25 (25%).

(Choice D)  The prevalence of exposure (ie, elevated CRP levels) in the entire cohort (all subjects, regardless of exposure/disease status) is 20/100 = 0.2 (20%).

(Choice E)  The prevalence of exposure in nondiseased people is 10/70 = ~0.14 (~14%).

Educational objective:
Risk is the probability of developing a disease over a certain period of time.  To calculate the risk, divide the number of exposed subjects with the disease by the total number of exposed subjects (ie, all subjects at risk).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText:
The abstract shown on the left applies to the next 2 items.

A 4-year-old girl is monitored at the hospital after undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) to repair an acyanotic congenital heart defect.  The procedure required aortic clamping, and CPB lasted 150 minutes.  Maximal lactatemia during CPB was 7 mmol/L, and laboratory studies showed moderate metabolic acidosis.  The patient subsequently develops postoperative ARF.

Item 1 of 2

Based on the abstract, which of the following was the most significant risk factor that contributed to this patient's developing postoperative ARF?
questionList.explanationText:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association used in case-control studies to compare the odds of exposure in cases (ie, individuals with disease) relative to controls (ie, individuals without disease):

OR = (odds of exposure in cases) / (odds of exposure in controls)

ORs may be unadjusted or adjusted:

  • An unadjusted OR estimates the association between a risk factor and an outcome but does not account (ie, control) for the effect of other variables, known as potential confounders (eg, patient demographics, clinical factors), on the outcome of interest.

  • An adjusted OR accounts for the effect of potential confounders, thereby minimizing confounding and providing better estimates of associations.

A confidence interval (CI) that includes the null value (ie, OR = 1.0) is not statistically significant, and a CI that excludes the null value is statistically significant.

This study provides unadjusted (bivariate) and adjusted (multivariable) ORs for several risk factors among patients who developed ARF (cases) compared to patients who did not (controls).  Unadjusted analysis shows that all risk factors are significantly associated with ARF (ie, CIs exclude the null value).  However, once potential confounders (ie, age, sex, duration of CPB) are controlled in the adjusted analysis, the only statistically associated risk factors (ie, CIs exclude the null value) are:

  • Moderate-to-severe hyperlactatemia: OR = 4.91; 95% CI: 1.26-19.05

  • Cyanotic heart disease: OR = 3.62; 95% CI: 1.11-11.63 (Choice A)

The CIs for CPB duration, metabolic acidosis, and aortic clamping in the multivariable (adjusted) analysis include the null value (OR = 1.0), so those risk factors are not statistically associated with ARF (Choices B, D, and E).  This implies that the variables controlled for in the adjusted analysis were distorting the true association between the risk factors and the outcome.

Based on these results, this patient's maximal lactate level of ≥6 mmol/L (ie, moderate-to-severe hyperlactatemia) is a risk factor for developing postoperative ARF; cyanotic heart defect is also a risk factor (ie, acyanotic heart defect is a protective factor).

Educational objective:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association between an exposure and an outcome.  Confidence intervals that contain the null value (ie, OR = 1.0) indicate that the association is not statistically significant.  Adjusted ORs minimize confounding and provide better estimates of associations.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Based on the abstract, which of the following is of most concern regarding this study?
questionList.explanationText:
Confounding bias occurs when a study does not control for extraneous variables independently related to both the risk factor and the outcome.  When not controlled, confounders may mask the true effect that the independent variable has on the dependent variable, which may lead to false conclusions (ie, statistically significant results that are truly invalid).

In this study, a bivariate (ie, unadjusted) analysis was conducted to identify potential risk factors for ARF among children undergoing surgery with CPB.  A multivariable (adjusted) analysis was also conducted to control for the effects of age, sex, and duration of CPB on the relationship between the risk factors (ie, aortic clamping, cardiac output syndrome, hyperlactatemia during CPB, metabolic acidosis, type of heart disease) and the outcome (ie, ARF).  However, there may be other important risk factors for ARF after CPB that the multivariable analysis did not control for, such as preoperative creatinine level, proteinuria, albuminuria, or ACE inhibitor use.  Therefore, limited adjustment for potential confounders may have led to residual confounding in the study.

(Choice A)  Differential mortality refers to differences in death rates between specific groups participating in follow-up studies (eg, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies).  Because this is a case-control study, patients are not followed across time and differential mortality is not applicable.

(Choice B)  Failure to show a statistically significant association between a risk factor and an outcome is often due to insufficient power (eg, due to a small sample size) to detect an association.  However, this study showed several statistically significant associations after adjusting for age, sex, and duration of CPB, suggesting sufficient power to detect these significant associations.  Additional statistically significant associations may be identified with a larger sample size (ie, more power) but would not negate established associations.

(Choice D)  Misclassification of cases occurs when the outcome (eg, disease) is not assessed correctly.  In this case-control study, cases were patients who developed ARF according to pRIFLE criteria, which standardize ARF classification based on creatinine clearance.  Therefore, cases are clearly defined and less likely to be misclassified.

Educational objective:
Confounding bias occurs when an extraneous (ie, confounding) variable masks the relationship between an independent variable (eg, risk factor, treatment) and a dependent variable (ie, outcome, disease of interest).  It may lead to false conclusions (ie, statistically significant results that are truly invalid).  Failure to adjust for potential confounding factors may lead to residual confounding and a distortion of the true relationship between variables.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Confounding, effect modification, bias, errors

answerChoiceList.choice: Differential mortality between cases and controls
Lack of power to detect any statistical associations

questionList.questionText: A clinical trial is conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new drug for migraine headache.  As part of the trial design, researchers set the statistical probability values for alpha and beta at 0.05 and 0.10, respectively, and a sample of 800 adult patients with chronic migraines, selected from patients who attend headache clinics at several major academic medical centers, are randomly assigned to receive the new drug or placebo.  Baseline scores on a standardized migraine disability assessment tool are obtained.  Analysis of the results after 6 months of treatment shows that the new drug is associated with a clinically significant improvement in scores on the assessment tool, with a p-value of 0.04.  Which of the following parameters would most likely have been greater if the study had been conducted using 300 subjects?
questionList.explanationText:
A type II error occurs when a false null hypothesis H0 is not rejected, that is, when a study does not find a statistically significant difference although one truly exists (ie, false negative).  The probability of a type II error (known as beta [β]) is the complement of statistical power (1 – β).  Statistical power is the probability of rejecting a false H0, that is, the ability to find a statistically significant difference when one truly exists (ie, true positive).

The power of a study is affected by its sample size.  Studies with larger sample sizes have greater power to detect differences between groups when one truly exists than do studies with smaller sample sizes.  This means that studies with smaller sample sizes have a greater probability of a type II error than do studies with larger sample sizes.  Type I errors (ie, a true H0 is rejected, resulting in a false positive) and type II errors are typically inversely related to each other—as one increases, the other decreases.  Therefore, a reduction in sample size results in a greater probability of a type II error and a lower probability of a type I error (known as alpha [α]).

In this example, results show that the new drug for migraines is clinically and statistically better than placebo in a study of 800 patients.  A study with a smaller sample size (eg, 300) would have had a lower power to detect such a difference if one truly existed (Choice E).  Subsequently, the study with the smaller sample size also would have had a greater probability of a type II error; it would also have resulted in a lower probability of a type I error (Choice A).

(Choices C and D)  Sensitivity and specificity are performance parameters of a diagnostic test.  Sensitivity is defined as the percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (ie, proportion of subjects who have a positive test result among all those with disease).  Specificity is defined as the percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (ie, proportion of subjects who have a negative test result among all those without disease).  This study is not evaluating the performance of a diagnostic test.

Educational objective:
Studies with larger sample sizes have greater power (ie, a false H0 is rejected) and therefore lower probability of a type II error than do studies with smaller sample sizes.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Power and sample size

answerChoiceList.choice: Likelihood of a type I error
Likelihood of a type II error

questionList.questionText:
A study was conducted to assess the association between hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in post-menopausal women and the level of serum C-reactive protein (CRP), categorized as "high" or "normal" based on predefined values.  The data from the study are presented below:

CRP highCRP normalTotal
HRT324173
No HRT284977
Total6090150

Which of the following is the best statistical method to assess the association between HRT and CRP levels?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (ie, continuous) based on the scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups, whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, risk factor) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

The chi-square test is used to compare the proportions of a categorized outcome with a qualitative (categorical) independent variable and a qualitative (categorical) dependent variable.  In this case, the outcome (CRP level) is categorized as either "high" and "normal," and then presented with the categorized exposure ("HRT" or "no HRT") in a 2 × 2 table.  In one of the commonly used chi-square tests, the observed values in each of the cells are compared to expected (under the hypothesis of no association) values.  If the difference between the observed and expected values is large, an association between the exposure and the outcome is assumed to be present.

(Choice A)  Correlation analysis measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables.  In the given 2 × 2 table, the variables are categorized (ie, qualitative rather than quantitative).

(Choices B and D)  The two-sample z-test and two-sample t-test are used to compare 2 means, not proportions.  Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means of ≥2 variables.

(Choice E)  Meta-analysis is an epidemiologic method of pooling the data from several studies to do an analysis having a relatively big statistical power.

Educational objective:
The chi-square test is used to compare proportions.  A 2 × 2 table may be used to compare the observed values with the expected values.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionList.questionText:
A group of researchers is investigating whether the availability of green spaces (eg, grass, forests, parks) within people's living environments is associated with depression-associated mortality.  Data of officially confirmed deaths related to depression during the past 10 years are collected in a random sample of counties across the United States.  A geographic information system is used to calculate the percentage of green spaces in each county.  During data analysis, the percentage of green spaces is categorized as low (≤25%), moderate (>25% to ≤85%), or high (>85%).  An excerpt of study results is shown below:

Green spaces

Relative risk of
depression-associated mortality*

95% confidence interval

Moderate

0.831

0.762-0.907

High

0.760

0.681-0.849

*Reference group = Low.

Which of the following is the best statement concerning the results of the study?
questionList.explanationText:
In this study, researchers collected county-level data on depression-associated mortality (eg, county-level proportion of death certificates where depression was listed as a contributing factor) and calculated the percentage of green spaces in each county to determine whether the presence of green spaces is associated with depression-associated mortality.  They did not collect any individual-level data.  This is consistent with an ecological study design, in which the rates of an outcome (eg, rate of depression-associated mortality) and exposures (eg, high percentage of green spaces) are measured at the population or community (eg, county) level, and their association is examined.

The results suggest that compared to counties with a low percentage of green space (reference group), counties with a moderate or high percentage of green space have a lower risk of depression-associated mortality because the corresponding relative risks (RRs) of 0.831 and 0.760 are both <1.  Both 95% confidence intervals for the RR exclude the null value of 1; this indicates that the results are statistically significant.  Therefore, the percentage of green spaces in living environments is significantly associated with depression-associated mortality.

Although ecological studies are commonly used to generate hypotheses and may establish associations between risk factors and outcomes, results from this type of study cannot establish causality (Choices A and B).  They are also not valid for making inferences regarding subjects (eg, individuals) within these populations because results offer information at the population (eg, county) level rather than at the subject level (Choices C and D).  This phenomenon is known as the ecological fallacy.  The fallacy assumes that individuals of a population all have the average characteristics of the population as whole, but any association observed between variables at the population level does not necessarily mean that the same association exists for any individual selected from the population (eg, a subject living in an environment with a high percentage of green spaces may not have a lower risk of depression-associated mortality).

Educational objective:
In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population.  Disease rates and exposures are measured in each of a series of populations, and their association is determined.  Therefore, results about associations at the population level may not translate to the subject level.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

answerChoiceList.choice: A high percentage of green spaces within living environments causes a significant decrease in depression-associated mortality
A high percentage of green spaces within living environments can prevent depression-associated mortality

An individual living in an environment with a high percentage of green spaces has a significantly lower risk of depression-associated mortality than an individual living in an environment with a low percentage of green spaces

An individual living in an environment with a high percentage of green spaces has the same risk of depression-associated mortality as an individual living in an environment with a low percentage of green spaces
There is a statistically significant association between the percentage of green spaces in living environments and depression-associated mortality

questionList.questionText: A medical student conducting a literature search about breastfeeding and HIV is reviewing a randomized controlled trial in which women who were HIV seropositive were randomly assigned to either breastfeed or formula feed their infants.  After delivery, mother-infant pairs were followed monthly during the first year and quarterly during the second year until the mother's death, or until 2 years after delivery.  The study reported that the cumulative mortality rate at 24 months after delivery was 11.2% in the breastfeeding group and 3.5% in the formula-feeding group (p = 0.02).  Based on these results, what is the approximate percentage of maternal deaths in the breastfeeding group that can be attributed to breastfeeding?
questionList.explanationText:
Attributable risk percentage (ARP) describes the percentage of disease in an exposed group that can be attributed to the exposure.  It is sometimes described as the percentage of disease in an exposed group that could be prevented by eliminating the risk factor.

ARP is calculated as the difference in risk of disease between an exposed group and a nonexposed group divided by the risk of disease in the exposed group:

ARP = [(Riskexposed − Risknonexposed) / Riskexposed] × 100

According to the article, the risk of disease (ie, death) in the exposed (ie, breastfeeding) group was 11.2% (or 0.112) (Choice C).  In the nonexposed (ie, formula-feeding) group, the risk was 3.5% (or 0.035) (Choice B).  Therefore:

ARP = [(Riskexposed − Risknonexposed) / Riskexposed] × 100 = [(0.112 − 0.035) / 0.112)] × 100 = 68.75%

Therefore, the approximate percentage of maternal deaths in the breastfeeding group that can be attributed to breastfeeding is 68.8%.

Alternately, ARP may be calculated using relative risk (RR):

ARP = [(RR – 1) / RR] × 100

For this example, RR is the ratio of risk of disease (ie, death) in the exposed (ie, breastfeeding) group to the risk of disease (ie, death) in the nonexposed (ie, formula-feeding) group.  It is calculated as:

RR = (Riskexposed / Risknonexposed) = (0.112 / 0.035) = 3.2 (Choice A)

Therefore:

ARP = [(RR − 1) / RR] × 100 = [(3.2 − 1) / 3.2] × 100 = 68.75% ~ 68.8%

For mothers with HIV, formula feeding is recommended in resource-rich settings but not in resource-poor settings where it is associated with increased infant mortality rates due to waterborne pathogens (diarrhea), pneumonia, and other infections.

(Choices B and D)  Absolute risk increase (ARI) is the difference in the risk of a negative outcome (eg, death) between an exposed (eg, breastfeeding) group and a nonexposed (eg, formula-feeding) group.  It is calculated as:

ARI = (Riskexposed − Risknonexposed) = (0.112 − 0.035) = 0.077 (or 7.7%)

Number needed to harm (NNH) is the number of people who must be exposed to a treatment to cause harm to 1 person who otherwise would not have been harmed.  It is calculated as:

NNH = 1 / ARI = 1 / 0.077 = 12.99 ~ 13 (not a percentage)

ARP is different from attributable risk, which is another name for the difference in absolute risks (eg, Riskexposed − Risknonexposed).

Educational objective:
Attributable risk percentage (ARP) describes the percentage of disease in an exposed group that can be attributed to the exposure.  It is calculated as the difference in risk of disease between the exposed and nonexposed groups divided by the risk of disease in the exposed group: ARP = [(Riskexposed − Risknonexposed) / Riskexposed] × 100
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Measures of association

questionList.questionText: A large clinical trial is performed to evaluate the treatment response to statins in statin-naive patients admitted for anginal chest pain.  Patients are randomly assigned to moderate- or high-dose statin therapy upon discharge.  At 3 months, the adverse cardiovascular event rate in the high-dose group compared to the moderate-dose group was 0.98 with a p value of 0.80.  At 1 year, the relative risk ratio was 0.67 with a p value of 0.01.  Treatment and follow-up compliance was high in both groups throughout the study interval.  The difference between the 2 risk estimates is best explained by which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Latency is an important natural phenomenon of disease epidemiology.  Most infectious diseases have relatively short latency periods (ie, the time elapsed from initial exposure to clinically apparent disease).  In contrast, some disease processes (eg, cancer, heart disease) have a long latency period before clinical manifestations develop.

The concept of a latency period can also be extended to risk factors and risk reducers.  Sometimes, a significant amount of time must pass before exposure to a risk modifier has a clinically evident effect on the disease process.  In addition, exposure to a risk modifier may need to occur continuously over a certain period before the disease outcome is affected.  In this case, at least 1 year of high-dose statin therapy was required to show a significant protective advantage over moderate-dose therapy.

(Choice A)  Confounding bias occurs when a perceived exposure-disease relationship is actually caused by an extraneous factor that correlates with both the exposure and the disease.  There is no information suggesting that confounding occurred in this study.

(Choice C)  Observer bias occurs when an observer misclassifies data due to individual differences in interpretation or preconceived expectations regarding the study.  It can be reduced by performing a double-blind study with multiple observers to encode and verify recorded data.

(Choice D)  Selection bias can occur with inappropriate (ie, nonrandom) assignment methods or through selective attrition of the study participants.  It results in a study population that does not accurately represent the actual population, leading to erroneous conclusions regarding the exposure-disease relationship.

(Choice E)  Selective survival bias occurs in case-control studies when cases are selected from the entire disease population instead of just those that are newly diagnosed.  For instance, a study on cancer survival that is not limited to newly diagnosed patients will contain a higher proportion of relatively benign malignancies as these patients generally live longer.

Educational objective:
The concept of a latency period can be applied to both disease pathogenesis and exposure to risk modifiers.  Exposure to risk factors and the initial steps in disease pathogenesis sometimes occur years before clinical manifestations are evident.  In addition, exposure to risk modifiers may need to be continuous over a certain period before influencing the outcome.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText: A new potential blood test for diagnosing Alzheimer disease is evaluated in Populations A and B.  The negative predictive value is estimated at 98% in Population A and at 85% in Population B.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questionList.explanationText:
The negative predictive value (NPV), the probability that an individual truly does not have a disease given a negative test result, is equal to the number of individuals without disease and who test negative (ie, true negatives [TN]) divided by all those with a negative test result (ie, TN + false negative [FN]):

NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

Similarly, the positive predictive value (PPV), the probability that an individual truly has the disease (ie, true positive [TP]) given a positive test result (including TP or false positive [FP] results), is given by:

PPV = TP / (TP + FP)

Predictive values depend on disease prevalence in a population of interest.  Specifically, disease prevalence affects NPV by changing TN and FN.

  • Populations with exceptionally low disease prevalence (eg, prevalence close to 0%) have almost all TN (ie, more TN) with almost no TP (ie, fewer TP), and most positive tests would be FP (ie, more FP) with almost no FN (ie, fewer FN).  This explains why NPV increases (more TN, fewer FN) and PPV decreases (fewer TP, more FP) with decreasing prevalence.

  • Populations with exceptionally high disease prevalence (eg, prevalence close to 100%) have almost all TP (ie, more TP) with almost no TN (ie, fewer TN), and most negative tests would be FN (ie, more FN) with almost no FP (ie, fewer FP).  This explains why NPV decreases (fewer TN, more FN) and PPV increases (more TP, fewer FP) with increasing prevalence.

In this case, the test has a higher NPV (98%) in Population A than in Population B (NPV = 85%).  This implies that Population A has a lower disease prevalence than Population B (Choice B).  Therefore, the proportion of patients without Alzheimer disease is greater in population A than in population B.

(Choice A)  The accuracy of a diagnostic test is the probability that an individual is correctly classified by the test: accuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN).  Because no information is given on these specific values, no conclusions regarding accuracy can be made.

(Choices D and E)  Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic test parameters that are not affected by disease prevalence.  The same test was used in Populations A and B, so there is no change in sensitivity and specificity.

Educational objective:
Predictive values depend on disease prevalence.  As disease prevalence increases, the positive predictive value increases and the negative predictive value decreases.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

answerChoiceList.choice: The accuracy of the test is greater in Population A than in Population B
The prevalence of Alzheimer disease is greater in Population A than in Population B
The proportion of patients without Alzheimer disease is greater in population A than in population B
The sensitivity of the test is lower in Population A than in Population B
The specificity of the test is greater in Population A than in Population B

questionList.questionText:
The abstract shown on the left applies to the next 2 items.

A 28-year-old primigravida woman comes to the office due to inability to conceive despite appropriately timed, unprotected intercourse for the past 6 months.  The patient has had no abnormal Pap tests.  She and her husband have no chronic medical conditions or previous surgeries.  The patient does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  She drinks >1 cup of coffee per day and is a moderate smoker.  Blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min.  BMI is 23 kg/m2.  Physical examination reveals a soft, nontender abdomen with no masses.  The patient's N-acetyltransferase 2 (NAT2) acetylator status is unknown.

Item 1 of 2

Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from the results of the study?
questionList.explanationText:
This study evaluated how caffeine, alcohol, and smoking associate with fecundability in women age 20-41 at risk for pregnancy.  The initial results (ie, unstratified analysis) show that fecundability is significantly associated with alcohol (ie, confidence interval [CI] for the odds ratio [OR] excluded the null value [OR = 1]) but not with caffeine or current smoking (ie, CIs included the null value).  A subsequent stratified analysis was conducted based on participants' N-acetyltransferase 2 (NAT2) acetylator phenotypes to determine whether NAT2 status (ie, slow or rapid acetylation) helps explain these associations.  The stratified analysis shows that some of these associations were inconsistent across NAT2 status (ie, slow or rapid acetylators).

  • Among slow acetylators, fecundability was significantly associated with alcohol and smoking because the CIs excluded the null value of OR = 1 (95% CI: 0.07 to 0.56 for NAT2/alcohol; 95% CI: 0.23 to 0.48 for NAT2/smoking).  However, fecundability was not significantly associated with caffeine because the CI included the null value of OR = 1 (95% CI: 0.67 to 1.62 for NAT2/caffeine).

  • Among rapid acetylators, fecundability was not significantly associated with caffeine, alcohol, or smoking because all CIs included the null value of OR = 1 (95% CI: 0.50 to 1.85 for NAT2/caffeine; 95% CI: 0.61 to 2.22 for NAT2/alcohol; 95% CI: 0.93 to 2.94 for NAT2/smoking) (Choice A).

Therefore, the effect of smoking and alcohol on fecundability is modified by NAT2 status—NAT2 status is an effect modifier.  Effect modification (interaction) occurs when an extraneous variable (effect modifier) changes the effect an exposure (eg, treatment) has on an outcome in certain groups of individuals but not others.  A stratified analysis based on the modifier can help detect effect modification because it typically shows different effects in each stratum.

(Choices B and D)  Based on the abstract, fecundability is not significantly associated with caffeine or NAT2 status because the corresponding CIs included the null value (95% CI: 0.58 to 1.38 for the association between fecundability and caffeine; 95% CI: 0.89 to 2.35 for the association between fecundability and NAT2 status).

Educational objective:
Effect modification occurs when the magnitude or direction of the effect of the independent variable on the dependent variable (outcome) varies depending on the level of a third variable (effect modifier).  Separate (stratified) analyses should be conducted for each level of the effect modifier.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Confounding, effect modification, bias, errors

answerChoiceList.choice: Alcohol has a significant effect on fecundability among rapid acetylators
Fecundability is significantly associated with NAT2 status
The effect of smoking and alcohol on fecundability is modified by NAT2 status
There is a significant association between caffeine and fecundability regardless of NAT2 status

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Assuming the patient has the slow acetylator phenotype, which of the following statements is most accurate?
questionList.explanationText:
Based on the stratified analysis in the abstract, the estimated odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) for the association between fecundability and caffeine, alcohol, and smoking among women with the slow acetylator phenotype were as follows:

  • Caffeine (≥300 mg/day vs <300 mg/day): OR = 0.81; 95% CI: 0.67 to 1.62

  • Alcohol (≥1 drinks/day vs <1 drink/day): OR = 0.20; 95% CI: 0.07 to 0.56

  • Smoking (current smoker vs nonsmoker): OR = 0.34; 95% CI: 0.23 to 0.48

The CIs for alcohol and smoking excluded the null value (OR = 1), suggesting that fecundability is significantly associated with alcohol and smoking.  In contrast, the CI for caffeine included the null value, suggesting that fecundability is not associated with caffeine (Choice C).  Because the corresponding ORs are <1, alcohol and smoking are associated with a significant decrease in the odds of fecundability (Choices A and D).  Therefore, women who have the slow acetylator phenotype have significantly lower odds of fecundability if they use alcohol or smoke.

(Choice B)  Based on the abstract, N-acetyltransferase 2 (NAT2) acetylator status alone is not significantly associated with fecundability (OR = 1.44; 95% CI: 0.89 to 2.35).  This indicates that NAT2 acetylator status is not independently associated with fecundability.  Therefore, having the slow acetylator phenotype does not affect fecundability.

Educational objective:
An odds ratio (OR) <1 indicates that the exposure (eg, caffeine) is associated with a decrease in odds of an outcome (eg, fecundability).  A confidence interval that excludes the null value (ie, OR = 1) is statistically significant.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Measures of association

answerChoiceList.choice: Caffeine, alcohol, and smoking significantly reduce the odds of fecundability in women with the slow acetylator phenotype
Having the slow acetylator phenotype significantly decreases the odds of fecundability
The only factor that significantly reduces the odds of fecundability among women with the slow acetylator phenotype is caffeine
There is no significant association between caffeine, alcohol, or smoking and fecundability among women with the slow acetylator phenotype
Women with the slow acetylator phenotype have significantly lower odds of fecundability if they use alcohol or smoke

questionList.questionText: A study is conducted to determine whether administration of recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (rhG-CSF) in the first trimester improves pregnancy outcomes among women with a history of unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss.  One hundred fifty women with a history of unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss are randomly assigned to receive either rhG-CSF or placebo.  Daily subcutaneous injections of rhG-CSF (130 mcg) or identical-appearing placebo are administered as early as 3-5 weeks gestation for a maximum of 9 weeks.  The primary outcome is clinical pregnancy at 20 weeks gestation, as demonstrated by ultrasound scan.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical measure to determine whether rhG-CSF influences the primary outcome in this study?
questionList.explanationText:
This study design is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) in which participants are initially randomly assigned to receive either a treatment (ie, recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor [rhG-CSF]) or a placebo according to the independent variable (ie, treatment, exposure).  Once participants are randomized into groups, the occurrence (ie, incidence, rate) of the dependent variable (ie, clinical pregnancy) within a specific period is determined in each group.  Finally, the rate of the outcome is compared between the treatment group and the placebo group to estimate the association between the treatment and the outcome.  A common measure of association in RCTs is relative risk (RR), calculated as follows:

RR = (rate of outcome in treatment group) / (rate of outcome in placebo group)

The RR may compare the rate (ie, risk) of an outcome between 2 different treatment groups, one of which serves as a control group, or between a treatment group and a placebo group.

The rationale for studying rhG-CSF in recurrent pregnancy loss is that it may modulate the immune response to the fetus.

(Choices A and B)  Hazard ratio and median survival are measures of association for time-to-event (survival) outcomes commonly used in cohort studies and experimental designs.  They compare total and median survival times, respectively, in ≥2 groups of patients (eg, those receiving a new treatment and those receiving a placebo).  However, this study does not have a time-to-event (survival) outcome.

(Choice C)  Odds ratio is calculated in case-control studies, in which 2 groups of individuals are initially identified as cases or controls according to an outcome (eg, disease of interest).  Finally, the frequency of exposure to the risk factors is compared between groups to estimate the association between the risk factors and the outcomes.

(Choice D)  Prevalence ratio is a ratio of 2 prevalence estimates commonly used in cross-sectional studies to compare the prevalence of disease among exposed and nonexposed groups of people.  In RCTs, the goal is to estimate and compare the incidence of an outcome in groups of individuals randomly assigned to one of several treatments or placebo.  Therefore, estimating the prevalence of disease in RCTs is not possible.

Educational objective:
A randomized controlled trial is used to estimate and compare the incidence of an outcome in groups of individuals randomly assigned to one of several treatments or placebo.  A common measure of association is relative risk.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.

Graduate students at a school of public health are analyzing the results of a study they conducted at a community health fair.  The students approached fairgoers at random and asked them if they would be willing to answer questions about health-related topics; 90% of those approached agreed to participate.  Using a prewritten questionnaire, the students asked the participants standardized questions and recorded the answers.  In addition to obtaining basic demographic data, students inquired about the amount of carbonated beverages consumed in each household and also asked participants to estimate prevalence of obesity in their household.  By comparing the demographic data they gathered to those from a recent official demographic census, the students determined that the fair was well attended by a representative sample of the community.  Their results suggest that the self-reported prevalence of obesity among household members is approximately 25% and that there is no association between household consumption of carbonated beverages and reported prevalence of obesity.

Item 1 of 2

Which of the following best describes the study design?
questionList.explanationText:
Types of studies in the health sciences

Experimental

Randomized controlled trial

  • Random allocation into treatment & placebo groups
  • Can determine efficacy of the intervention

Nonrandomized design

  • Nonrandom allocation into treatment & placebo groups
  • Can determine efficacy of the intervention

Observational

Cohort

  • Data gathered from the same individuals over time (longitudinal)
  • Can assess risk factors or outcomes

Cross-sectional

  • Data gathered at one point in time
  • Can determine prevalence of an outcome in a population

Case-control

  • Data gathered from individuals with the condition of interest (cases) & compared to individuals without the condition (controls)

Case

  • Detailed information gathered about one individual (or a small group of individuals)

Review

Meta-analysis

  • Data from multiple studies are statistically combined & analyzed

The students conducted a cross-sectional survey where they inquired about possible risk factors (eg, carbonated beverage consumption) and outcomes (eg, obesity) at a specific point in time ("snapshot").  Cross-sectional studies are examples of observational studies.  They are often relatively quick and easy to perform, are useful in determining prevalence of an outcome, and can serve to generate, but not test, hypotheses.

(Choice A)  In case-control studies, researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease/outcome of interest (eg, obesity) as cases and patients without the disease/outcome of interest as controls.

(Choice B)  The unit of analysis for ecological studies is populations rather than individuals.  For example, ecological longitudinal studies using national data showed that lung cancer rates increased 2 decades after smoking rates increased.  Although this suggested an association between smoking and lung cancer, the ecological studies did not link cases of lung cancers with individual smokers; case-control and cohort studies were needed to further study the association.

(Choice C)  Experimental (ie, interventional) studies would evaluate the impact of an intervention (eg, procedure, community-based intervention).  Examples include randomized controlled trials.

(Choice E)  Prospective cohort studies follow subjects over time; this survey provided a snapshot at a given point in time.

Educational objective:
Cross-sectional studies are examples of observational studies.  They are often relatively quick and easy to perform, are useful in determining prevalence of an outcome, and can serve to generate hypotheses.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

The students subsequently mail out an anonymous questionnaire to members of the same community.  The questionnaire is of similar length as the one administered during the fair, and the questions are phrased similarly.  The response rate and the demographics of the sample are comparable to those of the survey taken at the fair.  However, when the students analyze the data from the returned anonymous questionnaires, they find that the self-reported prevalence of obesity among household members is significantly higher than that estimated at the fair, and their results suggest that households with higher carbonated beverage consumption have a higher reporter prevalence of obesity.  Which of the following forms of bias is most likely responsible for these differences in results?
questionList.explanationText:
Study participants may over- or under-report exposure history due to perceived social stigmatization, resulting in reporting bias.  For example, while being interviewed directly by the students, the fairgoers may have under-reported carbonated beverage consumption and prevalence of obesity in their households due to concerns that they would be perceived negatively.  In contrast, respondents to an anonymous mailed questionnaire may have provided more accurate data.

Other potential sources of bias in this situation include observer/interviewer bias, as the student interviewers may have inadvertently influenced the fairgoers' responses by making gestures or emphasizing specific questions, and recall bias, as fairgoers may not have remembered the correct amount of carbonated beverages their household consumes (whereas participants filling out the mailed questionnaire at home may have found it easier to estimate or verify the correct amount).

(Choices A and D)  Ascertainment bias occurs when the results from an atypical population are extrapolated into the entire population; these study results have not been extrapolated to the population.  In addition, the response rate and demographic characteristics of the survey and the mailed questionnaire were comparable, making nonresponse bias less likely.

(Choice B)  Berkson bias occurs when controls are chosen among hospitalized patients only, resulting in a potential bias (hospitalized controls may have had an exposure related to the outcome of interest) and limiting generalizability.

(Choice C)  Neyman bias occurs if exposure is a prognostic factor that can impact survival.  Exposures that happen long before disease assessment can cause the study to miss diseased patients who die earlier.  In rapidly fatal diseases, the impact can be even more extreme.  For example, a hospital-based study on snow shoveling and myocardial infarction will miss patients who die in their driveways before reaching the hospital.

Educational objective:
Reporting bias may occur if subjects over- or under-report exposure history due to perceived social stigmatization.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText:
The abstract shown on the left applies to the next 2 items.

A 46-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  The patient has been following a standard diabetic diet and the same oral antidiabetic agent regimen for the past 8 months.  BMI is 25.2 kg/m2, waist circumference is 83 cm, and hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is 7.3%.  The patient recently read an article comparing a vegan diet to a standard diabetic diet in control of HbA1c levels.  An excerpt from the study abstract is shown.

Item 1 of 2

Based on the abstract, which of the following conclusions is most appropriate?
questionList.explanationText:
This study compared the effects of a vegan diet to a standard diabetic diet on glycemic control in select patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  The endpoints of the study were change in hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) level over 12 weeks (primary endpoint) and changes in BMI, waist circumference, and other variables (secondary endpoints).  Negative values for the changes (eg, −0.5) represent reductions; the standard deviations (eg, ±0.8) describe the spread of the changes (note that, even though some of the standard deviation values cross 0, they do not help determine statistical significance because they reflect spread and are NOT confidence intervals).

According to the footnote in the table, p-values < 0.01 for paired t-tests were considered statistically significant.

Based on the abstract:

  • HbA1c levels were significantly reduced in both the vegan and the standard groups (p < 0.01 for change in HbA1c in both groups), with a greater reduction in the vegan group (−0.5 ± 0.8) compared to the standard group (−0.2 ± 0.7).  Among participants with ≥90% compliance, the reductions in HbA1c levels were even larger (−0.9 in the vegan group, −0.3 in the standard group) (Choice D).  The p-values comparing the reductions between the 2 diet groups were statistically significant, regardless of compliance.
  • BMI was significantly reduced (p < 0.01) in the vegan group only.  Compared to the standard group (−0.1 ± 0.6), the vegan group had a greater reduction in BMI (−0.5 ± 0.9) at 12 weeks.
  • Waist circumference was significantly reduced (p < 0.01) in the vegan group only.  Compared to the standard group (−0.8 ± 4.6), the vegan group had a greater reduction in waist circumference (−3.1 ± 4.9).

Although both diets led to reductions in HbA1c levels, only the vegan diet helped to significantly reduce BMI and waist circumference.

(Choice A)  Although the baseline waist circumference values were 84.0 ± 9.8 in the vegan group and 82.3 ± 7.5 in the standard group, these differences likely are not statistically significant given how close these means are to each other and the magnitude of the standard deviation in each group (ie, vegan group 9.8 vs standard group 7.5).

(Choice C)  The vegan diet produced clinically significant reductions in HbA1c (eg, −0.5, −0.9), similar to those that can be achieved with pharmacotherapy.

Educational objective:
Statistically significant changes are reflected by a p-value less than a given significance level (eg, p < 0.01).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical vs. clinical significance

answerChoiceList.choice: Baseline difference in waist circumference between the participants in the vegan and the standard diabetic diet groups makes comparisons unreliable
Compared to participants in the standard diabetic diet group, participants in the vegan diet group had a greater, statistically significant reduction in BMI
None of the differences between Week 0 and Week 12 reported in the abstract demonstrates any clinical significance
Only participants with ≥90% compliance who followed a vegan diet showed a statistically significant decrease in HbA1c level at 12 weeks

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Which of the following recommendations is appropriate for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
The applicability of study results beyond the specific population studied depends on whether particular patients are similar to those studied.  This patient is a 46-year-old woman who has type 2 diabetes mellitus, a BMI of 25.2 kg/m2, and an HbA1c level of 7.3%; she has been following a standard diabetic diet and antidiabetic agent regimen for the past 8 months.  Based on the inclusion (ie, age 30-70; taking oral antidiabetic agents for ≥6 months; HbA1c level of 6%-10%) and exclusion (ie, increase in dose of antidiabetic agent or addition of new antidiabetic agent in past 3 months; current vegetarian; chronic renal failure) criteria described in the abstract, the study results may apply to her.

The study demonstrated that a vegan diet may be more helpful than a standard diabetic diet in decreasing HbA1c level, particularly among patients with a high (≥90%) compliance.  However, only 15 of 59 (~25%) of participants achieved ≥90% compliance in the vegan group.  Therefore, although a vegan diet likely would be beneficial to reduce this patient's HbA1c level, compliance may be difficult.

(Choice A)  The adequate follow-up time in a study depends on various factors, including the time required to observe a sufficiently large effect (eg, change in HbA1c level) in a study group to make valid statistical inferences (eg, 12-week follow-up chosen because HbA1c measures 3-month blood glucose averages).  Although a longer follow-up period may potentially clarify effect duration and identify longterm side effects, study reproducibility (ie, in similar conditions) is not likely to be affected by a limited follow-up period.

(Choice B)  Although blinding is commonly used in experimental studies to control for bias, there are some instances in which blinding participants is impossible, as in interventions consisting of diet regimens or surgery.

(Choice C)  Although BMI was not a criterion used to include or exclude participants in the study, having a BMI close to the study's baseline values helps make a better application of study results.  The patient's BMI (25.2 kg/m2) is within the range of the baseline BMI values in the study (eg, 23.9 ± 3.4); therefore, it does not suggest that the study results would not apply.

Educational objective:
The applicability of study results beyond the specific population studied depends on whether particular patients are similar to those studied.  Compliance to treatments can be an important factor.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Evidence-based clinical recommendations

answerChoiceList.choice: A vegan diet cannot be recommended because the study's limited follow-up period means that the results are not reproducible
A vegan diet cannot be recommended because the study's participants were not adequately blinded to the assigned diet
Although a vegan diet helped with weight loss in this study, the results may not apply to the patient given her BMI
Although a vegan diet may be more helpful than a standard diabetic diet in decreasing HbA1c level, the patient may find compliance difficult

questionList.questionText: A prospective cohort study was conducted to evaluate the long-term effects of a high-fat diet on the incidence of colon cancer.  The study participants were randomly selected from the population of interest.  Dietary patterns were assessed through the use of periodic self-completed questionnaires.  The investigators reported a 5-year relative risk of 1.60 for people who consumed a high-fat diet compared to individuals who consumed a low-fat diet.  The 95% confidence interval was 1.02 to 2.15.  This study is most likely to have which of the following p values?
questionList.explanationText:
Relative risk (RR) is the probability of the outcome of interest occurring in the exposed group compared to the probability of it occurring in the non-exposed group.  The null value of the RR is 1.0; a RR of 1.0 means that the outcome occurs with equal frequency in both groups and that there is no association between the exposure and the outcome.  A RR > 1.0 means that the outcome occurs more frequently in the exposed group (positive association).  The RR says nothing about the statistical significance of a study.

Statistical significance can be expressed with either p values or confidence intervals, but both are interrelated.  For instance, p < 0.05 corresponds to a 95% confidence interval that does not contain the null value.  Likewise p < 0.01 is equivalent to a 99% confidence interval that does not contain the null value.  Conversely, if the null value is within a given confidence interval, then the p value is > the equivalent confidence interval.

In general, for study results to be statistically significant, the 95% confidence interval must not contain the null value.  This is equivalent to p < 0.05, which means that there is less than a 5% chance that the results are due to chance alone.  In this case, the 95% confidence interval is 1.02 to 2.15 and does not contain the null value of 1.0.  This corresponds to p < 0.05, thus 0.04 is the only correct answer choice.

(Choices B, C, D, and E)  These p values are all > 0.05, meaning the associated 95% confidence interval would contain the null value.

Educational objective:
Confidence intervals and p values are interrelated and express the statistical significance of a study.  In a statistically significant study, p should be < 0.05.  This corresponds to a 95% confidence interval that does not include the null value.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText:
The drug ad applies to the next 2 items

The drug advertisement is focused on kalgatran (Kalaxin), a new oral anticoagulant for the treatment of non-valvular atrial fibrillation.

Item 1 of 2

Bleeding risk is the major concern when anticoagulating patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation.  The advertisement promotes Kalaxin as a safe medication.  In the study comparing Kalaxin and warfarin, which of the following specific bleeding risks were most similar between the 2 groups?
questionList.explanationText:
The drug advertisement is comparing the effect of Kalaxin versus warfarin for preventing stroke in non-valvular atrial fibrillation.  It compares the hazard rates for adverse events for both drugs in the form of hazard ratios.  A hazard rate is the chance of an event occurring in one of the study groups during a set period.  A hazard ratio is the chance of an event occurring in the treatment group compared to the chance of that event occurring in the control group during a set period.

A hazard ratio <1 indicates that an event is more likely to occur in the control group.  A hazard ratio >1 signifies that an event is more likely to occur in the treatment group.  A ratio close to 1 implies little difference between the 2 groups.  In this study, the hazard ratio for major bleeding was 0.96, which is the closest to 1 compared to the other answer options.  In addition, the 95% confidence interval (0.84-1.10) contains the null value of 1, indicating that there is no significant difference in the risk of major bleeding between the 2 groups.  This information is presented in the text below the bar graph.  As with any commercial entity, drug manufacturers may have incentive to maximize the visibility of a drug's benefits over its risks or side effects.  As a result, it is important to critically read all presented information when reviewing a drug advertisement.

(Choice A)  The hazard ratio for gastrointestinal bleeding is 1.75, indicating that Kalaxin has a higher chance of causing gastrointestinal bleeding than warfarin.  The hazard ratio for major gastrointestinal bleeding is 1.38.

(Choice B)  The hazard ratio for intracranial bleeding is 0.39, indicating that Kalaxin has a lower chance of causing intracranial bleeding than warfarin.

(Choice C)  The hazard ratio for life-threatening bleeding is 0.75, indicating that Kalaxin has a lower chance of causing life-threatening bleeding than warfarin.

(Choice E)  The hazard ratio for total bleeding is 0.91, indicating that Kalaxin has a slightly lower chance of causing overall bleeding than warfarin.

Educational objective:
Hazard ratios are proportions that indicate the chance of an event occurring in the treatment group compared to the chance of the event occurring in the control group.  When reviewing a drug advertisement, it is important to critically read all the presented information.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Randomized control trials

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

When assigning patients to treatment and control groups, proper randomization is important to avoid the effect of extraneous variables in the study results.  In the current study, which of the following forms of additional information would help most in determining randomization success?
questionList.explanationText:
In any randomized clinical study, the goal of successful randomization is to eliminate bias in treatment assignments.  An ideal randomization process minimizes selection bias, results in near-equal treatment and control group sizes, and achieves a low probability of having confounding variables.  A table of patient baseline characteristics for both treatment and control groups would show if the 2 groups included patients with similar features and would help confirm proper randomization.

(Choice A)  Annual stroke rate is an endpoint of the study that may be influenced by patient randomization, but it does not determine success of randomization.

(Choice C)  Patient compliance charts indicate how well a patient tolerated the treatment and followed the treatment regimen, but it would not directly indicate the success of randomization.

(Choice D)  Patient follow-up rates indicate how many patients followed up or dropped out of the study.  These data are not a direct marker of randomization success.

(Choice E)  Subgroup analysis tables (stratified analysis) are used to determine if certain patient characteristics (eg, age, comorbidities) influenced treatment to any significant extent.  Improper randomization can lead to inaccurate subgroup analysis results.

Educational objective:
Successful randomization in a clinical trial allows a study to eliminate bias in treatment assignments.  An ideal randomization process minimizes selection bias, results in near-equal treatment and control group sizes, and achieves a low probability of confounding variables.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Randomized control trials

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Statistical properties of randomization in clinical trials.

questionList.questionText:
A 26-year-old primigravida woman comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit.  The patient has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) and is worried about her pregnancy.  She read an article about pregnancy outcomes in women of similar age with EDS and wants to discuss the results.  The study compared several perinatal events in women with EDS to those in women without EDS.  A summary of the results is shown in the table below.

Perinatal events

Odds ratio*

95% confidence interval

Preterm birth

0.6

0.2-2.8

Induction of labor

2.9

1.9-4.6

Amniotomy

3.5

2.0-6.2

Cesarean delivery

0.8

0.3-1.6

Small-for-gestational-age birth

1.2

0.4-5.2

Large-for-gestational-age birth
