1.4

0.5-4.6

*Odds ratio adjusted for maternal age, smoking history, BMI, parity, and year of birth.

Based on the study results, which of the following conclusions is strongly justified?
questionList.explanationText:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association used in case-control studies to compare the odds of exposure in cases (ie, individuals with disease) relative to controls (ie, individuals without disease):

OR = (odds of exposure in cases) / (odds of exposure in controls)

The OR may be interpreted as follows:

  • OR <1.0 indicates that the exposure is associated with a decrease in odds of disease with respect to no exposure (ie, the exposure is a protective factor).

  • OR = 1.0 (null value) indicates that there is no association between the exposure and the disease.

  • OR >1.0 indicates that the exposure is associated with an increase in odds of disease with respect to no exposure (ie, the exposure is a risk factor).

The confidence interval (CI) of an OR indicates, with a certain confidence level, whether a given OR is statistically different from the null value (ie, OR = 1.0).  A CI that includes the null value is not statistically significant, and a CI that excludes the null value is statistically significant (at that confidence level).

In this study, results show that Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) increases the odds of amniotomy because OR >1.0; the change (OR = 3.5 compared to OR = 1) represents an increase of 250% ([3.5 − 1]/1 = 2.5 = 250%), with a 95% CI: 2.0-6.2.  The calculations are based on the principle that an OR = 1 (null value) does not increase the odds (ie, OR = 1 corresponds to a 0% change in odds), so an OR = 2 increases odds by 100% (not 200%), and so on.  Similarly, EDS also increases the odds of induction of labor by 190%, or about 200% (OR = 2.9 compared to OR = 1; 95% CI: 1.9-4.6) (Choice D).  Because neither CI includes the null value (ie, OR = 1.0), these associations are statistically significant (Choice E).

(Choices A and C)  EDS does not appear to be significantly associated with preterm birth (OR = 0.6; 95% CI: 0.2-2.8), cesarean delivery (OR = 0.8; 95% CI: 0.3-1.6), small-for-gestational-age birth (OR = 1.2; 95% CI: 0.4-5.2), or large-for-gestational-age birth (OR = 1.4; 95% CI: 0.5-4.6) because each CI contains the null value of 1.0.

Educational objective:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association between an exposure and a disease.  For OR <1.0, the exposure decreases the odds of disease (ie, protective factor).  For OR = 1.0, there is no association between exposure and disease.  For OR >1.0, the exposure increases the odds of disease (ie, risk factor).  Confidence intervals that contain the null value (ie, OR =1.0) indicate that the association is not statistically significant.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Measures of association

answerChoiceList.choice: EDS is a protective factor for preterm birth and cesarean delivery
EDS significantly increases the odds of amniotomy by about 250%
Small- and large-for-gestational-age births are more likely in women with EDS than in women without EDS
The odds of induction of labor are about 30% higher in women with EDS than in women without EDS
There is no significant difference in perinatal events between women with and without EDS

questionList.questionText:
An observational study was conducted to evaluate the association between exposure to a certain hazardous chemical and cancer.  The study population included individuals who were employees of a chemical company when the company had a chemical accident 10 years ago.  Company records were used to identify potential participants.  Individuals enrolled in the study were categorized by their level of exposure to the hazardous chemical: no exposure, minimal exposure, moderate exposure, or severe exposure.  Databases were used to determine the status (cancer, cancer free) of employees in each group.  The number of cancer cases for each level of exposure was as follows:

  • No exposure (n = 200): 10 cases
  • Minimal exposure (n = 120): 12 cases
  • Moderate exposure (n = 160): 28 cases
  • Severe exposure (n = 120): 40 cases

Which of the following expressions would provide a value closest to the relative risk of developing cancer for employees with at least a minimal level of exposure compared to nonexposed employees?
questionList.explanationText:
Relative risk (RR) is used in cohort studies to estimate the association between exposure and disease.  It compares risk of disease (eg, cancer) in an exposed group (eg, exposure to a hazardous chemical) relative to a nonexposed group (eg, no exposure to a hazardous chemical).  The RR can be calculated based on the incidence of disease in the exposed group divided by the incidence of disease in the nonexposed group.

RR = (incidence in exposed group) / (incidence in nonexposed group)

Using the results from this study, the RR of cancer can be determined for employees with at least a minimal level of exposure compared to nonexposed employees.  The exposed group includes 3 exposure levels (ie, minimal, moderate, severe), and the nonexposed group includes 1 exposure level (ie, no exposure).  The incidence of cancer for exposed and nonexposed groups is calculated as follows:

  • The exposed group consisted of 400 (= 120 + 160 + 120) employees with at least a minimal level of exposure, of which 80 (= 12 + 28+ 40) had cancer, for an incidence of 80 / 400.

  • The nonexposed group consisted of 200 employees with no exposure, of which 10 had cancer, for an incidence of 10 / 200.

Therefore, the expression that would provide the RR of developing cancer for employees with at least a minimal level of exposure compared to nonexposed employees is:

RR = (80 / 400) / (10 / 200)

(Choice A)  The expression (80 / 400) − (10 / 200) provides the risk difference for cancer between employees with at least a minimal level of exposure and nonexposed employees.

(Choices B and E)  These expressions, (10 × 320) / (80 × 190) and (80 × 190) / (10 × 320), provide odds ratios (ORs).  The first gives the OR of cancer for at least a minimal level of exposure relative to no exposure, and the second gives the OR for no exposure relative to at least a minimal level of exposure.

(Choice C)  The expression (10 / 200) / (80 / 400) provides the RR of cancer for nonexposed employees compared to employees with at least a minimal level of exposure.

Educational objective:
Relative risk (RR) is a measure of association used to compare the incidence of disease in an exposed group relative to a nonexposed group.  It is calculated as:

RR = (incidence in exposed group) / (incidence in nonexposed group)
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText: A clinical study is conducted to assess the role of a vasopressin antagonist in overall survival of patients with advanced heart failure and hyponatremia.  After providing informed consent, eligible hospitalized patients are administered either the new drug or a matching placebo along with the appropriate standard care.  Assignment to the 2 treatment arms is done randomly using computer-generated numbers.  This assignment strategy is most helpful for controlling which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
The effects of confounding bias can be reduced through good study design and proper analysis of the results.  Methods used to control for confounding during data analysis include stratified analysis and statistical modeling (eg, multivariate analyses).  In addition, methods to control for confounders during study design include the following:

  1. Matching: Frequently used in case-control studies, this method involves matching known or suspected confounding variables between the cases and controls.  For example, if smoking status is a known confounder, then controls will be selected on a case-by-case basis so that there are similar numbers of smokers and nonsmokers in both the case and control groups.
  2. Restriction: This method involves limiting study participation to individuals with specific characteristics.  For example, if sex is thought to be a confounder, then a restricted study may enroll only men.  However, this method is limited as the study results may not be applicable to the excluded population (ie, women).
  3. Randomization: Commonly employed in clinical trials, this technique helps to balance the distribution of confounding variables between treatment and placebo groups so that the unconfounded effect of the exposure of interest can be isolated.  An important advantage of randomization, compared to other methods, is the possibility of controlling known risk factors (eg, age and severity of heart failure) as well as the unknown and difficult-to-measure confounders (eg, level of stress and socioeconomic status).

Randomization also eliminates partiality in treatment assignments, minimizing selection bias.

(Choice B)  Effect modification results when an external variable positively or negatively impacts the effect of a risk factor on the disease of interest.  For instance, the risk of venous thrombosis is increased with estrogen therapy, and this effect is augmented by smoking.

(Choice C)  Post-hoc analysis refers to performing unplanned statistical tests on patterns that were identified after the fact in data from a completed study.  This can lead to incorrect conclusions, particularly if the appropriate statistical measures have not been taken to account for these additional tests.  Post-hoc analysis can be problematic with non-predefined subgroup analysis.  Randomization does not directly impact post-hoc analysis (which can be conducted even on data from randomized samples).

(Choice D)  Recall bias results from inaccurate recall of past exposure and applies primarily to retrospective studies.  People who have suffered an adverse event are more likely to recall risk factors than people without such experiences.

(Choice E)  Selective survival bias occurs in case-control studies when cases are selected from the entire disease population instead of just those that are newly diagnosed.  For instance, a study on cancer survival that is not limited to newly diagnosed patients will contain a higher proportion of relatively benign malignancies as these patients generally live longer.

Educational objective:
Randomization is used to control for confounders during the design stage of a study.  It helps to control for known, unknown, and difficult-to-measure confounders.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Confounding, effect modification, bias, errors

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) due to clinical suspicion for sepsis.  The patient's parents agree to let him participate in an ongoing clinical study to assess the utility of IL-27 in predicting bacterial infection among patients with bloodstream infections who are admitted to the PICU.  A blood sample is obtained and reveals an IL-27 value of 5 ng/mL.  A previously published study that compared several cut points for IL-27 with positive blood cultures showed that an IL-27 value ≥5 ng/mL has a sensitivity of 26% and a specificity of 95%.  In considering how this patient's IL-27 value might influence treatment decisions, which of the following conclusions about the study results is correct?
questionList.explanationText:
Positive condition

Negative condition

Positive test result

TP

FP

PPV =
TP / (TP + FP)

Negative test result

FN

TN

NPV =
TN / (TN + FN)

Sensitivity =

TP / (TP + FN)

Specificity =

TN / (TN + FP)

FN = false negative; FP = false positive; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value; TN = true negative; TP = true positive.

Compared to blood culture (the reference standard for diagnosing bacterial bloodstream infection), an IL-27 cut point of ≥5 ng/mL has a sensitivity of 26% and a specificity of 95%.

  • The specificity of the test is the percentage of individuals (eg, critically ill pediatric patients) without a condition (eg, bacterial bloodstream infection) who are correctly identified (ie, negative test result) by the diagnostic test.  Its complement (100% − specificity) is the false-positive rate (eg, percentage of critically ill pediatric patients without bacterial bloodstream infection who test positive).

  • The sensitivity of the test is the percentage of individuals (eg, critically ill pediatric patients) with a condition (eg, bacterial bloodstream infection) who are correctly identified (ie, positive test result) by the diagnostic test.  Its complement (100% − sensitivity) is the false-negative rate (eg, percentage of critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infection who test negative).

The specificity of 95% means that 95% of critically ill pediatric patients without bacterial bloodstream infection will be correctly identified (ie, test negative) based on the IL-27 cut point of ≥5 ng/mL (ie, test result <5 ng/mL).  Conversely, 100% − 95% = 5% will be incorrectly identified (ie, false-positive rate) (Choice D).

The sensitivity of 26% means that 26% of critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infection will be correctly diagnosed (ie, test positive) based on the IL-27 cut point of ≥5 ng/mL (Choices A and C).  Therefore, 100% − 26% = 74% of patients with bacterial bloodstream infection will be missed (ie, test negative with a result <5 ng/mL) (Choices E and F).

Educational objective:
Sensitivity represents the probability that an individual with disease will have a positive test result.  Specificity represents the probability that an individual without disease will have a negative test result.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

answerChoiceList.choice: Based on a cut point of ≥5 ng/mL, 5% of critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infections will be correctly identified
Based on a cut point of ≥5 ng/mL, 5% of critically ill pediatric patients without bacterial bloodstream infections will be incorrectly identified
Based on a cut point of ≥5 ng/mL, 95% of critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infections will be correctly identified
Based on a cut point of ≥5 ng/mL, 95% of critically ill pediatric patients without bacterial bloodstream infections will be incorrectly identified
Of all critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infections, 5% will have an IL-27 value <5 ng/mL
Of all critically ill pediatric patients with bacterial bloodstream infections, 95% will have an IL-27 value <5 ng/mL

questionList.questionText:
A group of scientists developed a new quantitative test to diagnose a childhood disease that is lethal if left untreated.  The distribution of patients who have the disease and who are disease-free according to their values on the new test are shown below.

If the treatment for the disease is safe and inexpensive, which of the points labeled on the graph represents the best diagnostic cutoff for the disease?
questionList.explanationText:
In this example, scientists developed a new quantitative test to diagnose a childhood disease that is lethal if left untreated.  For this type of disease, the consequences of a false-negative diagnostic error are catastrophic because a patient incorrectly diagnosed as not having the disease will certainly die as a result.  Therefore, the cutoff for diagnosis should be set at a point that guarantees that among all subjects with disease, the proportion who have a positive test result is as high as possible (ie, maximum sensitivity) given the safety and cost of available treatments.

The treatment for the disease under study is safe and inexpensive, which means that treating patients who are disease-free causes little to no harm.  In this case, a false-positive diagnostic error (which may lead to inappropriate but safe and inexpensive treatment) is less consequential than a false-negative diagnostic error (which leads to death).  Therefore, the best cutoff for the quantitative test would be a point that guarantees all patients who have the disease are correctly diagnosed (100% sensitivity).

On the graph given, the cutoff that guarantees 100% sensitivity is point B.  If this point is selected as a cutoff, test values higher than B will be considered a positive test result.  All patients with the disease have values higher than B; therefore, they will all be correctly diagnosed as having the disease (100% sensitivity).  Similarly, if points C, D, or E are selected as cutoff points, values higher than these will be considered a positive test but some patients with the disease will be missed (false negatives) (Choices D and E).  If point A is selected as a cutoff point, many patients without the disease will be incorrectly diagnosed as having the disease (false positives) (Choice A).

(Choice C)  Point C also misses some patients with the disease (ie, those who have values lower than C).  Given its location in the middle of the disease and disease-free symmetric curves, it represents the cutoff that results in the greatest diagnostic accuracy (ie, greatest proportion of patients with and without the disease are correctly identified).

Educational objective:
The cutoff of a test used to diagnose a lethal disease should guarantee the maximum sensitivity possible, considering the safety and cost of available treatments.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText: A group of researchers plans to conduct a case-control study to evaluate the association between colorectal cancer and evidence of past use of the weight-loss treatment drug lorcaserin.  Which of the following corresponds with the proposed study design?
questionList.explanationText:
A case-control study is a type of analytical observational study design in which potential participants are initially identified as "cases" or "controls" according to an outcome status (ie, disease or condition of interest).  In this question, individuals with colorectal cancer are cases and individuals without colorectal cancer are controls.  Once identified, cases and controls are then assessed for past exposure to ≥1 risk factors of interest.

The risk factor is past use of the weight-loss treatment drug lorcaserin.  The frequency of exposure to the risk factor is measured and compared between cases and controls to estimate the association between the risk factor and outcomes of interest.  In other words, the frequency of prior lorcaserin use (ie, risk factor) should be compared among patients with (ie, cases) and without (ie, controls) colorectal cancer.

(Choice A)  A case-control study begins by identifying individuals based on outcome or disease status (eg, colorectal cancer), not risk factor status (eg, history of lorcaserin use).

(Choice B)  Controls without a history of lorcaserin use represent a portion of the control group.  Excluding these individuals will result in a frequency of exposure to the risk factor (eg, history of lorcaserin use) of 100% in the control group, which is incorrect.

(Choices C and E)  A cohort study (not a case-control study) would begin by identifying individuals as exposed or nonexposed to a risk factor (eg, history of lorcaserin use) and end by comparing outcome rates (eg, cancer incidence) between the exposed and nonexposed groups.

Educational objective:
A case-control study is an observational study design.  It begins with individuals who have the outcome (ie, cases) and compares them with individuals who do not have the outcome (ie, controls), according to a history of exposure to ≥1 risk factors.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

answerChoiceList.choice: Cases should be identified as individuals with a history of lorcaserin use
Controls without a history of lorcaserin use should be excluded from the study
The frequency of colorectal cancer should be compared in individuals with and without a history of lorcaserin use at the beginning of the study
The frequency of prior lorcaserin use should be compared among individuals with and without colorectal cancer
The study should begin by identifying individuals based on their history of lorcaserin use

questionList.questionText: A group of researchers conducted a prospective cohort study to evaluate the association between caffeine consumption and the risk of colon cancer in women.  A total of 200 women age 40-60 participated in the study.  The statistical analysis controlled for factors such as amount of caffeine consumed per day, caffeine consumption changes during follow-up time, and other factors related to both caffeine consumption and colon cancer.  Results showed that caffeine consumption was associated with a statistically significant decrease in the risk of colon cancer with a relative risk of 0.83 (p = 0.02).  Researchers concluded that women in general could significantly reduce the risk of colon cancer if they increased their caffeine consumption.  Which of the following is most likely to invalidate the researchers' conclusion?
questionList.explanationText:
Internal validity

External validity

Characteristics

Describes causality (ie, if change in independent variable causes change in dependent variable)

Describes generalizability (ie, if observed relationship applies to situations or people outside study)

↑ As study becomes more tightly controlled

↓ As study becomes more tightly controlled

↓ As study becomes more like the real world

↑ As study becomes more like the real world

Threats to validity

Bias due to:

  • Confounding
  • History
  • Maturation
  • Measurement
  • Regression toward the mean
  • Repeated testing
  • Selection

Bias due to:

  • Artificial research environment
  • Measurement effects
  • Nonrepresentative sample

The external validity (or generalizability) of a study is the applicability of study results beyond the specific population studied.  This cohort study evaluated the association between caffeine consumption and the risk of colon cancer in women age 40-60 (ie, middle-aged women).  Although study results showed that caffeine consumption was associated with a statistically significant decrease in the risk of colon cancer (ie, relative risk = 0.83; p = 0.02), it is unknown whether the association holds for other populations of women (eg, younger women age <40, elderly women age >60).  Therefore, these study results may not apply to women in general.

(Choice B)  Internal validity is concerned with how well results provide evidence of a causal relationship in a study; it is affected by bias (eg, confounding bias, selection bias).  In this study, the statistical analysis controlled for potential confounders (ie, amount of caffeine consumed per day, caffeine consumption changes during follow-up time, other factors related to colon cancer) but no other description of how the study was designed or conducted was provided.  Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the internal validity was affected (ie, if bias is present).

(Choices C and D)  Reproducibility (reliability) refers to the extent to which a measure produces consistent results if the measurements are repeated multiple times.  Information on how repeated measurements of variables (eg, caffeine consumption, changes in consumption) were collected over time is not provided, so it is not possible to determine whether the measurements were reproducible (reliable).

(Choice E)  Statistical power is the ability of a study to detect a significant association (eg, decrease in risk of colon cancer) when that association exists.  This study was able to detect a statistically significant association between caffeine consumption and colon cancer, so the study had sufficient statistical power.

Educational objective:
The external validity (or generalizability) of a study is the applicability of results beyond the specific population studied.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Validity And Reliability

questionList.questionText:
A randomized controlled trial of drug X is performed in adult patients hospitalized with a severe viral respiratory tract infection.  Drug X had previously been shown in vitro to inhibit cell entry of this specific virus.  Based on a power analysis, 78 patients are enrolled in the trial, half of whom are randomized to the intervention arm (standard care + drug X) and the other half to the control arm (standard care).  The outcome of the trial is viral load in the patients' blood samples, obtained by daily PCR measurements.  The percentage of patients with a positive viral load is compared between the groups.  Data from 18 patients in the intervention group and 2 patients in the control group are not included in the final data analysis because these patients died from cardiopulmonary arrest.  The results are summarized below:

% of patients with positive viral load by PCRp-value
Intervention groupControl group
Day 01001000.36
Day 194900.12
Day 282840.08
Day 315610.02
Day 43420.01

When reporting the results, the researchers highlight the difference in viral load after 3 days of treatment with drug X as evidence that the drug is effective.  Which of the following raises the most concern about the validity of the study results?
questionList.explanationText:
This study evaluated the effectiveness of drug X in adult patients hospitalized with a severe viral respiratory tract infection.  The results of the study showed a trend toward decreasing viral load in both groups, and the group difference was statistically significant after the second day (eg, p-value <0.05 starting on Day 3).  The researchers highlighted that as time progressed, patients receiving drug X had a significantly lower viral load than those receiving standard care.

However, 18 patients (ie, 46% of 39 patients) receiving standard care plus drug X and 2 patients (ie, 5% of 39 patients) receiving only standard care were not included in the final data analysis due to death from cardiopulmonary arrest.  This differential loss to follow-up is concerning; it may be related to the exposure (ie, drug X), suggesting that drug X may increase the likelihood of death.  Differences between the 2 groups are possible but less likely given the randomization process.

In this case, researchers reported the significant difference in viral load between groups but did not acknowledge the relatively large number of deaths among patients receiving drug X, thus introducing bias favoring drug X (Choices A and D).  Differential loss to follow-up is a subtype of selection bias and represents a threat to the internal validity of the study (Choice E).

(Choice C)  A power analysis was conducted, and the minimum number of patients was estimated at 78, with 39 patients receiving standard care plus drug X and 39 receiving only standard care.  Based on this analysis, the study had an adequate sample size for each group.

Educational objective:
Differential loss to follow-up is a subtype of selection bias and represents a threat to the internal validity of a study.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

answerChoiceList.choice: Decreasing trend in viral load in both groups
Large number of patients lost to follow-up
Small number of patients in each of the 2 groups
Statistically insignificant results at Days 0, 1, and 2
There is no concern about the validity of the study results

questionList.questionText: A prospective cohort study was conducted to assess the effects of oral contraceptive (OC) use on the incidence of breast cancer.  A crude analysis of the study suggests an association between OC use and breast cancer (relative risk [RR] = 1.40, 95% confidence interval [95%CI]: 1.01, 1.96).  Further analysis shows that in women with a family history of breast cancer, OC use increases the risk of breast cancer (RR = 3.33, 95%CI: 2.51, 4.41).  In women without a family history of breast cancer, a significantly smaller effect is observed (RR = 1.27, 95%CI: 1.01, 1.60).  The results of this study are best explained by which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Effect modification (interaction) results when an extraneous variable (modifier) changes the direction or strength of an association between a risk factor and a disease.  A modifier is associated with the disease but not the risk factor.  Effect modification can sometimes be confused with confounding, the bias that results when the exposure-disease relationship is obscured by the effect of an extraneous factor (confounder) associated with both exposure and disease.

Stratified analysis by the extraneous variable can help distinguish whether that variable is a confounder or an effect modifier, as follows:

  • Confounder (left panel):  The measures of association (eg, relative risk [RR] of bladder cancer among alcohol users) calculated in each of the stratified groups (eg, smokers and nonsmokers) are similar to one another (eg, nonstatistically significant RR = 0.95 [95%CI: 0.51, 1.76] and RR = 1.03 [95%CI: 0.34, 3.13]), but they differ from the measure of association calculated in the crude analysis (eg, statistically significant RR = 1.81 [95%CI: 1.06, 3.10]); stratification can remove the effects of the confounder (eg, smoking).

  • Effect modifier (right panel):  The measures of association calculated in each of the strata are significantly different (in strength or direction) from one another; stratification can make the effects of the modifier more apparent.

In this example, family history of breast cancer (BC) modifies the association between oral contraceptive (OC) use and BC.  Crude analysis reveals a significant association (ie, RR = 1.40 [95%CI: 1.01, 1.96]) between OC use and BC.  However, once the association is stratified by family history of BC, the strength of the association changes (ie, with BC family history, RR = 3.33 [95%CI: 2.51, 4.41]; with no BC family history, RR = 1.27 [95%CI: 1.01, 1.60]), reflecting a significantly higher risk for BC among those who take OCs if they also have a positive BC family history.  In other words, positive BC family history acts as an effect modifier.

(Choice A)  Given that the measures of association are significantly different from one another at the strata level (RR = 3.33 [95%CI: 2.51, 4.41] vs RR = 1.27 [95%CI: 1.01, 1.60]), BC family history is not a confounder.

(Choice C)  Latency period is the time required for a given exposure to have a measurable effect on the outcome.  This study provided no information on how long oral OCs must be used to have an effect on BC risk in susceptible patients.

(Choices D and E)  Observer bias and selection bias are errors in study design involving misclassification of data and inappropriate selection of participants, respectively.

Educational objective:
Effect modification results when an external variable positively or negatively impacts the effect of a risk factor on the disease of interest.  Stratified analysis helps determine whether a variable is a confounder or an effect modifier.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Confounding, effect modification, bias, errors

questionList.questionText: A resident conducts a case-control study to evaluate the association between the use of diuretics and bladder cancer.  A sample of 100 patients with bladder cancer is randomly selected from the state cancer registry, and a sample of 100 patients who have been admitted for any reason other than cancer is randomly selected from the resident's hospital.  The resident then evaluates medical charts to determine the frequency of past or current use of diuretics among cases and controls.  The results of the study reveal that past or current use of diuretics has a significant protective effect against bladder cancer (odds ratio: 0.75; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.67-0.89).  The resident's results contrast with the findings from a population-based study in which the incidence of bladder cancer is equal among those who use diuretics and those who do not (relative risk: 1.01; 95% CI: 0.92-1.25).  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the resident's study results?
questionList.explanationText:
This study evaluates the association between diuretic use (exposure) and bladder cancer (outcome).  Cases are patients with bladder cancer from a cancer registry, and controls are patients who were hospitalized at a specific hospital for reasons other than cancer.

Results show that diuretic use is a protective factor against bladder cancer given the odds ratio (OR) = 0.75 (<1), which is statistically significant (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.67-0.89; does not include the null value OR = 1).  However, these results contradict those from a population-based study in which there is no difference in bladder cancer incidence between patients who use diuretics and patients who do not (relative risk: 1.01; 95% CI: 0.92-1.25).  This inconsistency may be related to the frequency of exposure in the control group.

Diuretic use is likely more common among hospitalized patients; therefore, a sample of hospital controls will likely have a higher-than-usual frequency of exposure in this study (ie, control group may not represent target population).  As a result, the measure of association (eg, OR) is biased.  The bias is usually toward the null (ie, no association or weaker association); however, in some instances the frequency of the exposure in the control group is so high (compared to the case group) that the direction of the association is reversed, as in this study in which diuretic use was found to have a protective effect (despite having no association with bladder cancer).

This phenomenon is known an Berkson bias—a type of selection bias in which hospitalized controls have a higher frequency of exposure than the general population meant to be represented.

(Choice A)  Attrition bias refers to an unequal loss of participants from study groups in follow-up (eg, cohort) studies.  Case-control studies do not include a follow-up period.

(Choice B)  Observer bias occurs when the investigator is aware of the exposure status, treatment group, or outcome of the participants and their ability to collect or record the data in an unbiased manner is compromised.

(Choice C)  Recall bias refers to the inaccurate recollection of past events.  It is a potential problem for case-control studies that rely on questionnaires or interviews to collect data about distant past exposure.

(Choice D)  Response bias occurs when participants in cross-sectional or case-control studies (eg, surveys, polls, questionnaires) purposely give desirable responses to questions about topics perceived to be sensitive (eg, health behaviors).

Educational objective:
Berkson bias is a type of selection bias; it occurs when controls are chosen from among hospitalized patients only, resulting in a potential bias (eg, hospitalized controls may have an exposure related to the outcome of interest) and limiting generalizability.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText: A study compares the efficacy of postpartum oral cephalexin in combination with metronidazole versus placebo to decrease surgical site infection rates among women with obesity who have already received standard preoperative antimicrobial prophylaxis and undergone cesarean delivery.  The absolute risk reduction between the cephalexin-metronidazole group and the placebo group is 10.0%.  In the placebo group, the surgical site infection rate is 16.0%.  In the cephalexin-metronidazole group, there are 12 patients with surgical site infection.  Based on this information, which of the following is the approximate number of patients in the cephalexin-metronidazole group?
questionList.explanationText:
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) describes the difference in the rate (or risk) of an unfavorable outcome between the treatment group (eg, new treatment) and the control group (eg, standard treatment):

ARR = (Riskcontrol − Risktreatment)

In this study, Riskcontrol is the rate of surgical site infections in the group treated with placebo and Risktreatment is the rate of surgical site infections in the group treated with cephalexin-metronidazole.  It is given that ARR = 0.10 (ie, 10%) and Ratecontrol is 0.16 (ie, 16%); therefore, the value of Ratetreatment is:

ARR = Ratecontrol – Ratetreatment
0.10 = 0.16 – Ratetreatment
Ratetreatment = 0.16 − 0.10 = 0.06

Ratetreatment is equal to the number of surgical site infections in the cephalexin-metronidazole group divided by the number of patients in that group (ie, sample size, n).  Therefore, it is possible to use the calculated Ratetreatment (ie, 0.06) and the given number of surgical site infections in the cephalexin-metronidazole group (ie, 12) to determine the sample size n of that group as follows:

Ratetreatment = (number of infections) / n
0.06 = 12 / n
n= 200

The number of patients in the cephalexin-metronidazole group is 200.

Educational objective:
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) describes the difference in the rate (or risk) of an unfavorable outcome between control and treatment groups.  It is calculated as follows: ARR = (Ratecontrol – Ratetreatment).  The rate of an unfavorable outcome is equal to the number of unfavorable outcomes in a group divided by the sample size of that group.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk, rate, prevalence and incidence

questionList.questionText: A large, multicenter study was conducted to determine the efficacy of pegfilgrastim, a new drug developed to reduce the risk of febrile neutropenia (FN) in patients with early-stage breast cancer.  One thousand women age 40-69 with stage I-III invasive breast carcinoma who were scheduled to receive cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy were enrolled in the study and randomly assigned to receive either placebo (500 women) or pegfilgrastim (500 women) at a dose previously shown in a small trial to have biological activity.  Results showed that the incidence of FN was significantly lower in the pegfilgrastim group than in the placebo group, and that patients in the pegfilgrastim group required fewer hospitalizations and lower antibiotic usage related to FN.  Most adverse events were consistent with those expected for breast cancer subjects receiving cyclophosphamide-based chemotherapy.  Researchers concluded that pegfilgrastim is safe and significantly reduces the incidence of FN in breast cancer patients.  Which of the following best describes this type of study?
questionList.explanationText:
The clinical trials process addresses whether new treatments (eg, drugs, procedures) are effective and safe for their intended use (eg, treatment of disease) in the target population (eg, patients with the disease of interest).  New treatments go through several research phases: some phases involve no human subjects (ie, preclinical studies) (Choice A); and some involve few (ie, phase I and II trials) or many (ie, phase III and IV trials) human subjects.

A phase III trial assesses treatment efficacy and human safety (eg, evaluates long-term or rare adverse effects).  It compares a new treatment to standard treatments (or placebo) in a large sample of affected patients (ie, patients with the disease of interest).  Most phase III trials are randomized and blind (ie, patients/researchers are unaware of treatment assignment), and may compare ≥2 treatments.  Results determine whether a new treatment is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for a commercial market.

In this question, the study evaluated the efficacy of a new treatment (ie, pegfilgrastim) in reducing the risk of disease (ie, febrile neutropenia) in affected patients (ie, early-stage breast cancer) who were randomly assigned to the new treatment compared to placebo.  This process is consistent with a phase III trial.

(Choice B)  A phase I trial assesses toxicity, maximum tolerated dose, adverse effects, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a new treatment, usually in a small number of healthy subjects.  This study involved a large sample of affected patients and was aimed at assessing efficacy.

(Choice C)  A phase II trial assesses efficacy, optimal dosing, and adverse effects of a new treatment in a small (rather than a large) number of affected patients (ie, patients with the disease of interest).  Some phase II trials may have ≥1 group, but these are generally small in sample size.

(Choice E)  A phase IV trial studies adverse effects caused over time by a new treatment after it has been approved and is on the market, as in a study to assess long-term adverse effects related to use of pegfilgrastim in breast cancer patients.

Educational objective:
Phase III trials evaluate the efficacy, risks, and benefits of a new treatment compared to current standard treatments (or placebo) in a large sample of affected patients (ie, patients with the disease of interest).  Most phase III trials are randomized, blind, and compare ≥2 treatments.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Clinical trials

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Key concepts of clinical trials: a narrative review

questionList.questionText: A group of medical geneticists hypothesizes that epidermal growth factor (EGF) could induce colorectal cancer (CRC) cells to undergo epithelial-mesenchymal transition, thereby enhancing their ability to invade and migrate.  The group wants to study the relationship between EGF gene polymorphism and CRC.  It plans to determine EGF A61G polymorphism by using PCR-restriction fragment length polymorphism method in 249 patients diagnosed with CRC and in 261 patients without a diagnosis of CRC.  Which of the following is the most appropriate null hypothesis for this study?
questionList.explanationText:
A statistical hypothesis is an initial assumption, which may or may not be true, regarding population parameters (eg, mean values in two different groups) or the relationship between variables within a population (eg, association between an exposure and a disease).  The null hypothesis (H0) is a statement of no difference or no association.  The alternative hypothesis (Ha) is a statement of difference or association.

In this case, patients are initially identified based on their disease status (ie, cases: patients with colorectal cancer [CRC]; controls: patients without CRC).  The frequency of exposure (ie, epidermal growth factor [EGF] A61G polymorphism) is subsequently compared between cases and controls.  Therefore, this is a case-control study.  The most appropriate measure of association between an exposure and a disease in case-control studies is the odds ratio (OR), which represents the odds of exposure among cases relative to controls.

The OR may be interpreted as follows:

  • OR = 1.0 (null value) indicates that the odds of exposure among cases are the same as the odds of exposure among controls; therefore, exposure is not associated with the disease.

  • OR ≠ 1.0 indicates that the odds of exposure among cases are lower (ie, OR <1) or higher (ie, OR >1) than among controls; therefore, exposure is associated with the disease.

The OR is sometimes described as the odds of disease among exposed patients relative to nonexposed patients; these two OR definitions are mathematically equivalent.

Because H0 is a statement of no association, the most appropriate H0 for the study is that the OR = 1 (Choice D).

(Choices A, B, E, and F)  Measures of association based on risk/incidence, such as relative risk and hazard ratio (eg, used in comparing 2 Kaplan-Meier survival curves), are calculated in cohort studies and experimental designs.  In such designs, participants are initially selected based on exposure status (ie, exposed or nonexposed to a risk factor or treatment) and then followed over time to assess development of disease.  By contrast, in case-control studies, cases (by definition) already have the disease.  Therefore, case-control studies cannot calculate and compare the risk/incidence of disease between the case and control groups; instead, they must compare the odds of exposure (to a risk factor) between cases and controls.

Educational objective:
The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association used in case-control studies.  It quantifies the relationship between an exposure and a disease; its null value (ie, null hypothesis) is always 1 (ie, OR = 1).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Case control studies

answerChoiceList.choice: Hazard ratio is not equal to 1
Odds ratio is not equal to 1
Relative risk is not equal to 1

questionList.questionText:
The drug advertisement in the exhibit button applies to the next 2 items. 

A 24-year-old woman is hospitalized for lupus nephritis.  She has had multiple hospitalizations in the past for nephritis.  She speaks with her nephrologist about promotional material from a pharmaceutical company that conducted a randomized, placebo-controlled trial for a monoclonal antibody, LupMAB, in the treatment of patients with lupus nephritis.  The trial compared LupMAB + standard therapy to standard therapy alone.

Item 1 of 2

Which of the following most likely represents the odds ratio and 95% confidence interval of achieving a renal response among patients who received LupMAB + standard therapy compared to those who received standard therapy alone?
questionList.explanationText:
This study compared the efficacy of LupMAB (a monoclonal antibody) + standard therapy (either mycophenolate mofetil [MMF] or cyclophosphamide-azathioprine [CA]) to standard therapy alone for lupus nephritis.  The primary outcome of the study was renal response evaluated at 6-week intervals.  Results showed that patients who received LupMAB + standard therapy had 55% greater odds of renal response compared to patients who received standard therapy alone.

The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association between an exposure to a risk factor and an outcome.  OR is usually defined as the odds of an exposure in cases divided by the odds of the same exposure in controls.  However, it may also be defined as the odds of disease among exposed patients (eg, treatment group) relative to nonexposed patients (eg, control group).  These two OR definitions are mathematically equivalent.

OR = (odds of disease in treatment group) / (odds of disease in control group)

A value of OR > 1.0 indicates that the exposure (eg, treatment) is associated with an increase in odds of outcome.  Because the odds of renal response in the treatment group (ie, LupMAB + standard therapy) is 55% greater compared to the control group (standard therapy alone), OR = 1.55 (ie, 155%) (Choices C and D).

The confidence interval (CI) of an OR indicates, with a certain confidence level, whether a given OR is statistically different from the null value (ie, OR = 1.0).  A CI that excludes the null value is statistically significant (at that confidence level).  A result that is statistically significant based on the 95% CI would also be statistically significant based on a value of p < 0.05.  In this trial, given that the renal response rate between groups was statistically significant (43% vs 32%; p = 0.031), the 95% CI must not contain the null value (ie, OR = 1.0) (Choice F).  Therefore, the OR in this study is likely 1.55 with a 95% CI (1.01-2.31).

(Choices A and B)  A value of OR < 1 (eg, OR = 0.45) indicates that the exposure (eg, treatment) is associated with a decrease in the odds of the outcome.  In this case, an OR = 0.45 indicates that there is a 1 − 0.45 = 0.55 (or 55%) lower odds of the outcome, but the promotional material states that the treatment was associated with greater odds of the outcome.

Educational objective:
An odds ratio (OR) value of OR > 1 indicates that the exposure (eg, treatment) is associated with an increase in odds of an outcome.  A confidence interval that excludes the null value (ie, OR = 1.0) is statistically significant.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical vs. clinical significance

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

The patient asks the physician whether LupMAB-based therapy is recommended.  Based on the promotional material, which of the following is the best response to this patient's inquiry?
questionList.explanationText:
Study results showed that 43% of patients receiving LupMAB + standard therapy achieved renal response compared to 32% of patients receiving standard therapy alone, with a statistically significant result given the value p < 0.05.  This translates into an absolute difference of 11% (43 − 32 = 11%).

The relative difference of (43 − 32) / 32 = 34% is greater than the absolute difference.  For this reason, journal articles and promotional materials often prefer to show the relative difference to emphasize the positive effect of the drug; however, absolute measures generally provide a more realistic idea of the true impact.  Similarly, highlighting the odds of 55% makes the effect appear more pronounced.

(Choice A)  This study compared the efficacy of a combined therapy (ie, LupMAB in combination with standard therapy) to standard therapy alone; therefore, it is not possible to determine the efficacy of LupMAB as a monotherapy to treat lupus nephritis.

(Choice B)  Subgroup analyses showed that, compared with placebo, more patients receiving LupMAB + mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) achieved renal response with a statistically significant result.  Similarly, more patients receiving LupMAB + cyclophosphamide-azathioprine (CA) achieved renal response, but the difference was not statistically significant.  The CA subgroup was smaller (eg, larger sample may have shown statistical significance) and had a greater proportion of patients with more advanced renal disease at baseline, raising the possibility that advanced disease (rather than CA treatment) affects response to LupMAB therapy.  Because of the smaller sample size, the differences in disease severity, and the lack of detailed information regarding prior treatment plans, offering specific recommendations based on subgroup analyses would be suboptimal.

(Choice D)  A study may be powered to detect differences in some effects but not others.  This study showed a statistically significant difference in odds of renal response, indicating that it had the power (ie, it was not underpowered) to detect such a result.  The frequency of adverse drug events, including low numbers of death events, was not statistically different between the intervention and the placebo groups, which may or may not reflect sufficient power to detect such differences; however, this provides no information on the power to detect a difference in odds of renal response.

(Choice E)  A confidence interval for the odds ratio is not necessary because the p-value already established that the difference in renal response between groups is statistically significant.

Educational objective:
Journal articles and promotional material may highlight relative measures to emphasize the positive effect of an intervention.  However, absolute measures generally provide a more realistic idea of true impact.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Evidence-based clinical recommendations

answerChoiceList.choice: LupMAB 5 mg/kg can be recommended as monotherapy based on the results of this study
LupMAB 5 mg/kg + standard therapy can be recommended but only if she was previously treated with MMF rather than CA
LupMAB 5 mg/kg + standard therapy can be recommended but the absolute difference in renal response compared to standard therapy alone is likely lower than 55%
LupMAB 5 mg/kg should not be recommended because the low numbers of death events suggests that the study was underpowered to show a significant difference in odds of renal response
LupMAB 5 mg/kg should not be recommended because the statistical significance of the results at week 90 cannot be determined without a confidence interval

questionList.questionText: A large study is conducted to assess the association between altitude and life expectancy.  Researchers obtained data on life expectancy at the county level from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and collected altitude data from the US Geological Survey.  A regression was used to model the association between altitude and life expectancy at the county level in 3,064 counties in the contiguous US while also controlling for several well-established covariates.  Which of the following best describes the design of this study?
questionList.explanationText:
In this study, researchers collected:

  • county-level data on life expectancy from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and
  • altitude data from the US Geological Survey

to determine whether altitude is associated with life expectancy.

Using population-level (eg, county, state, country), rather than individual-level, data as a unit of analysis in such a manner is consistent with an ecological study.  Ecological studies are useful for generating hypotheses but should not be used to draw conclusions regarding individuals within these populations because statistical relationships observed in a population (ie, a collection of individuals) may not hold true within all of the subgroups that make up that population.

For example, this study may show that altitude is significantly associated with longer life expectancy at the county level when, in fact, altitude is significantly associated with shorter life expectancy in certain groups within a county (eg, people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).  This apparent paradox is known as ecological fallacy.

(Choices A and B)  Cohort and cross-sectional studies deal with individuals rather than populations.  In cohort studies, individuals with and without different exposures (eg, residing in high- or low-altitude locations) are followed over time to compare outcomes (eg, life expectancy).  In cross-sectional studies, individuals are assessed for exposure to risk factors and disease simultaneously at a given point in time ("snapshot") to determine whether risk factors are associated with disease (at the individual level).  The overall design of this multicounty study relies on population-level data, not individual-level data.

(Choice D)  Qualitative studies use focus groups, interviews (structured and semi-structured), and other anthropologic techniques to obtain narrative information for explaining quantitative results.

(Choice E)  Systematic reviews and meta-analyses combine the results of several published studies (with an emphasis on high-quality, randomized controlled studies) to estimate the pooled effect.

Educational objective:
In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population, not the individual.  Disease rates and exposures are measured in each of a series of populations and their associations determined.  Results about associations at the population level may not translate to the individual level.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

abstractList.text:
Title

Alcohol, smoking, and caffeine in relation to fecundability and NAT2

Objective

To investigate how alcohol, smoking, and caffeine associate with fecundability and determine whether the most common polymorphisms in the N-acetyltransferase 2 (NAT2) metabolic enzyme help explain these associations.

Methods

Design:  Prospective study of fertility and menstrual function.  Follow-up for an average of eight menstrual cycles.

Participants:  295 women age 20-41 at risk for pregnancy.

Exposure:  Caffeine categorized into mean caffeine intake <300 mg/day and ≥300 mg/day.  Alcohol categorized into <1 drink/day and ≥1 drinks/day.  Smoking categorized into smokers and nonsmokers.  NAT2 acetylator status categorized into slow and rapid NAT2 acetylator phenotypes.

Outcome:  Fecundability.

Results

In general, fecundability was not associated with caffeine (odds ratio [OR] = 0.89; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.58 to 1.38) or current smoking (OR = 1.04; 95% CI: 0.65 to 1.67).  Alcohol use was significantly associated with reduced fecundability (OR = 0.50; 95% CI: 0.28 to 0.89).  However, the associations were inconsistent across NAT2 status.  NAT2 status alone was not significantly associated with fecundability (OR = 1.44; 95% CI: 0.89 to 2.35).

Conclusion

This research suggests the need to incorporate genetic information about metabolic enzymes to better interpret and understand the effects of xenobiotics on human health.

Title

Postoperative acute renal failure (ARF) in pediatric patients undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).

Objective

To identify risk factors associated with postoperative ARF according to the Pediatric Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-Stage Renal Disease (pRIFLE) scale in children undergoing cardiac surgery with CPB.

Methods

Design:  Case-control study.

Participants:  455 children age <16 who were admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit after cardiac surgery that required CPB.  Cases were patients who developed some degree of ARF according to pRIFLE criteria (n = 155); controls were patients who did not develop ARF (n = 300).

Exposure:  Cardiac surgery requiring CPB.

Outcome:  Pediatric postoperative ARF.

Objective

To compare the effects of a brown rice–based vegan diet to a standard diabetic diet on glycemic control.

Methods

Design:  Open, randomized controlled trial without participant blinding.

Follow-up period:  0, 12 weeks.

Participants:  118 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Inclusion criteria: age 30-70; taking oral antidiabetic agents for ≥6 months; hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) level of 6%-10%.  Exclusion criteria: increase in dose of antidiabetic agent or addition of new antidiabetic agent in past 3 months.

Intervention:  Vegan diet (n = 59) versus standard diabetic diet (n = 59) for 12 weeks.  Compliance reported based on a self-assessment daily dietary record allowing standardized conversion to a percentage scale.

Outcomes:  Primary endpoints: change in HbA1c level over 12 weeks.  Secondary endpoints include change in BMI and in waist circumference.
